17656.text: §¶The vision about Judah and Jerusalem that Isaiah, Amoz’s son, saw in the days of Judah’s kings Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.

17657.text: §¶Hear you heavens, and listen earth,/_for the Lord has spoken:/I reared children; I raised them,/_and they turned against me!

17658.text: /An ox knows its owner,/_and a donkey its master’s feeding trough./_But Israel doesn’t know;/_my people don’t behave intelligently.

17659.text: ¶Doom! Sinful nation, people weighed down with crimes,/_evildoing offspring, corrupt children!/They have abandoned the Lord,/_despised the holy one of Israel;/_they turned their backs on God.

17660.text: ¶Why do you invite further beatings?/_Why continue to rebel?/Everyone’s head throbs,/_and everyone’s heart fails.

17661.text: /From head to toe, none are well—/_only bruises, cuts, and raw wounds,/_not treated, not bandaged,/_not soothed with oil.

17662.text: ¶Your country is deserted,/_your cities burned with fire;/_your land—strangers are devouring it in plain sight./_It’s a wasteland, as when foreigners raid.

17663.text: /Daughter Zion is left like a small shelter in a vineyard,/_like a hut in a cucumber field,/_like a city besieged.

17664.text: /If the Lord of heavenly forces had not spared a few of us,/_we would be like Sodom; we would resemble Gomorrah.

17665.text: §¶Hear the Lord’s word, you leaders of Sodom./_Listen to our God’s teaching,/_people of Gomorrah!

17666.text: /What should I think about all your sacrifices?/_says the Lord./I’m fed up with entirely burned offerings of rams/_and the fat of well‑fed beasts./_I don’t want the blood of bulls, lambs, and goats.

17667.text: /When you come to appear before me,/_who asked this from you,/_this trampling of my temple’s courts?

17668.text: /Stop bringing worthless offerings./_Your incense repulses me./New moon, sabbath, and the calling of an assembly—/_I can’t stand wickedness with celebration!

17669.text: /I hate your new moons and your festivals./_They’ve become a burden that I’m tired of bearing.

17670.text: /When you extend your hands,/_I’ll hide my eyes from you./Even when you pray for a long time,/_I won’t listen./Your hands are stained with blood.

17671.text: /_Wash! Be clean!/Remove your ugly deeds from my sight./_Put an end to such evil;

17672.text: /_learn to do good./Seek justice:/_help the oppressed;/_defend the orphan;/_plead for the widow.

17673.text: ¶Come now, and let’s settle this,/_says the Lord./Though your sins are like scarlet,/_they will be white as snow./If they are red as crimson,/_they will become like wool.

17674.text: /If you agree and obey,/_you will eat the best food of the land.

17675.text: /But if you refuse and rebel,/_you will be devoured by the sword./The Lord has said this.

17676.text: §¶This faithful town has become a prostitute!/She was full of justice;/_righteousness lived in her—/_but now murderers.

17677.text: /Your silver has become impure;/_your beer is diluted with water.

17678.text: /Your princes are rebels,/_companions of thieves./Everyone loves a bribe and pursues gifts./_They don’t defend the orphan,/_and the widow’s cause never reaches them.

17679.text: /Therefore, says the Lord God of heavenly forces,/_the mighty one of Israel:/Doom! I will vent my anger against my foes;/_I will take it out on my enemies,

17680.text: /_and I will turn my hand against you./I will refine your impurities as with lye,/_and remove all your cinders.

17681.text: /Then I will restore your judges as in earlier times,/_and your counselors as at the beginning./After this you will be called Righteous City, Faithful Town.

17682.text: ¶Zion will be redeemed by justice,/_and those who change their lives by righteousness.

17683.text: /But God will shatter rebels and sinners alike;/_those who abandon the Lord will be finished.

17684.text: ¶You will be ashamed of the oaks you once desired,/_and embarrassed by the gardens you once chose.

17685.text: /You will be like an oak with withering leaves,/_like a garden without water.

17686.text: /The strong will be like dry twigs,/_their deeds like sparks;/_the two will burn together,/_with no one to extinguish them.

17687.text: §¶This is what Isaiah, Amoz’s son, saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

17688.text: ¶In the days to come/_the mountain of the Lord’s house/_will be the highest of the mountains./_It will be lifted above the hills;/_peoples will stream to it.

17689.text: /Many nations will go and say,/“Come, let’s go up to the Lord’s mountain,/_to the house of Jacob’s God/_so that he may teach us his ways/_and we may walk in God’s paths.”/Instruction will come from Zion;/_the Lord’s word from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /God will judge between the nations,/_and settle disputes of mighty nations./Then they will beat their swords into iron plows/_and their spears into pruning tools./Nation will not take up sword against nation;/_they will no longer learn how to make war.

17691.text: ¶Come, house of Jacob,/_let’s walk by the Lord’s light.

17692.text: §¶You have abandoned your people,/_house of Jacob./_They are full of sorcerers from the east and fortune‑tellers like the Philistines;/_they hold hands with foreigners’ children.

17693.text: /Their land is full of silver and gold;/_they have countless treasures./Their land is filled with horses;/_they have countless chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is filled with idols;/_they worship their handiwork,/_what their own fingers have made.

17695.text: ¶Humanity will be brought down;/_each person laid low—don’t lift them up!

17696.text: /Go into the rocks,/_and hide yourself in the dust from the terror of the Lord,/_from the splendor of God’s majesty!

17697.text: /People’s proud gazing will be stopped/_and humanity’s arrogance brought down;/_the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.

17698.text: ¶The Lord of heavenly forces has planned a day:/_against all that is prideful and haughty;/_against all that is lofty, and it will be laid low;

17699.text: /_against all the cedars of Lebanon, high and lofty;/_against all the oaks of Bashan;

17700.text: /_against all the high mountains;/_against all the lofty hills;

17701.text: /_against every tall tower;/_against every fortified wall;

17702.text: /_against all the ships of Tarshish;/_against all the wonderful boats.

17703.text: /People’s pride will be brought down/_and human arrogance humiliated./The Lord alone will be exalted on that day;

17705.text: ¶Go into caves in the rocks/_and holes in the dust/_before the terror of the Lord/_and the splendor of God’s majesty,/_when he arises to terrify the earth.

17706.text: /On that day, people will toss/_to the rodents and to the bats/_their idols of silver and idols of gold,/_which they made for themselves to worship.

17707.text: /They will hide in fissures of rocks and in crevices of cliffs/_before the terror of the Lord/_and the splendor of God’s majesty/_when he arises to terrify the earth.

17708.text: ¶Quit admiring the human race,/_who breathe through their nostrils./_Why should they be admired?

17709.text: §¶Now the Lord God of heavenly forces is removing from Jerusalem and from Judah every form of support:¶▼all rations of food and water;

17710.text: /_soldier and warrior;/_judge and prophet;/_fortune‑teller and elder;

17711.text: /_commander and celebrity;/_counselor, clever craftsman, and cunning charmer.

17712.text: /I will make youths their commanders;/_mischief makers will rule over them.

17713.text: /The people will oppress each other,/_each one against the other, neighbor against neighbor./_The young will bully the old,/_the rogue, and the respectable.

17714.text: ¶Someone will seize a family member, saying, “You have clothing! You be our leader!/This mess will be your responsibility!”

17715.text: /Someone else will cry out on that day,/_“I’m no healer!/_I have neither food nor clothing in my house!/_Don’t make me the leader of the people!”

17716.text: ¶Yes, Jerusalem has stumbled/_and Judah has fallen,/_because the way they talk and act in word and deed insults the Lord,/_defying his brilliant glory.

17717.text: /Their bias in judgment gives them away;/_like Sodom, they display their sins in public./_Doom to them, for they have done themselves in!

17718.text: /Tell the righteous how blessed they are;/_they will eat the fruit of their labors.

17719.text: /Doom to the wicked; they are evil./_What they have done will be done to them.

17720.text: /As for my people—oppressors strip them/_and swindlers rule them./My people—your leaders mislead you and confuse your paths.

17721.text: ¶The Lord arises to accuse;/_he stands to judge the peoples.

17722.text: /The Lord will enter into judgment/_with the elders and princes of his people:/You yourselves have devoured the vineyard;/_the goods stolen from the poor are in your houses.

17723.text: /How dare you crush my people/_and grind the faces of the poor?/_says the Lord God of heavenly forces.

17724.text: ¶The Lord says:/Because Zion’s daughters applaud themselves,/_walking with their chins in the air,/_flirting with their eyes,/_tiptoeing as they walk, feet jingling—

17725.text: /_the Lord will shave the heads of Zion’s daughters,/_and will expose their scalps.

17726.text: /On that day, the Lord will remove:/_the splendid ankle chains; headbands and moon‑shaped pendants;

17728.text: /_the hats, bangles, and sashes;/_the amulets and charms;

17730.text: /_the robes and capes;/_the shawls and handbags;

17731.text: /_the mirrors and linen garments;/_the turbans and the veils.

17732.text: /Instead of perfume there will be a disgusting odor;/_instead of a sash, a rope;/_instead of styled hair, shaved heads;/_instead of expensive clothes, rags as mourning clothes;/_instead of beauty, shame.

17733.text: ¶Your men will fall by the sword,/_your warriors in battle!

17734.text: /Her gates will lament and mourn;/_desolate, she will sit on the ground.

17735.text: ¶Seven women will grab one man on that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes—only let us take your name; take away our disgrace.”

17736.text: §¶On that day, the Lord’s branch will become beautiful and glorious. The earth’s fruit will be the pride and splendor of Israel’s survivors.

17737.text: Whoever remains in Zion and is left in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who is on the list of those living in Jerusalem.

17738.text: When the Lord washes the filth from Zion’s daughters, and cleanses Jerusalem’s bloodguilt from within it by means of a wind of judgment and a searing wind,

17739.text: then the Lord will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over its assembly a cloud by day and smoke and the light of a blazing fire by night. Over all the glory there will be a canopy,

17740.text: which will be a booth by day for shade from the heat and a hiding place and shelter from a stormy downpour.

17741.text: §¶Let me sing for my loved one/_a love song for his vineyard./My loved one had a vineyard on a fertile hillside.

17742.text: /He dug it,/_cleared away its stones,/_planted it with excellent vines,/_built a tower inside it,/_and dug out a wine vat in it./He expected it to grow good grapes—/_but it grew rotten grapes.

17743.text: /So now, you who live in Jerusalem, you people of Judah,/_judge between me and my vineyard:

17744.text: /What more was there to do for my vineyard/_that I haven’t done for it?/When I expected it to grow good grapes,/_why did it grow rotten grapes?

17745.text: /Now let me tell you what I’m doing to my vineyard./I’m removing its hedge,/_so it will be destroyed./I’m breaking down its walls,/_so it will be trampled.

17746.text: /I’ll turn it into a ruin;/_it won’t be pruned or hoed,/_and thorns and thistles will grow up./I will command the clouds not to rain on it.

17747.text: /The vineyard of the Lord of heavenly forces is the house of Israel,/_and the people of Judah are the plantings in which God delighted./God expected justice, but there was bloodshed;/_righteousness, but there was a cry of distress!

17748.text: §¶Doom to those who acquire house after house,/_who annex field to field until there is no more space left/_and only you live alone in the land.

17749.text: /I heard the Lord of heavenly forces say this:/Many houses will become total ruins,/_large, fine houses, with no one living in them.

17750.text: /Ten acres of vineyard/_will produce just one bath,/_and a homer of seed/_will produce only an ephah.

17751.text: ¶Doom to those who wake up early in the morning to run after beer,/_to those who stay up late, lit up by wine.

17752.text: /They party with lyre and harp, tambourine, flute, and wine;/_but they ignore the Lord’s work;/_they can’t see what God is doing.

17753.text: ¶Therefore, my people go into exile since they didn’t understand—/_their officials are dying of hunger;/_so many of them are dried up with thirst.

17754.text: /Therefore, the grave opens wide its jaws,/_opens its mouth beyond all bounds,/_and the splendid multitudes will go down, with all their uproar and cheering.

17755.text: /Humanity will be humiliated;/_each person laid low,/_the eyes of the exalted laid low.

17756.text: /But the Lord of heavenly forces will be exalted in justice,/_and the holy God will show himself holy in righteousness.

17757.text: /Lambs will graze as if in their pasture;/_young goats will feed among the ruins of the rich.

17758.text: ¶Doom to those who drag guilt along with cords of fraud,/_and haul sin as if with cart ropes,

17759.text: /_who say, “God should hurry and work faster so we can see;/_let the plan of Israel’s holy one come quickly, so we can understand it.”

17760.text: ¶Doom to those who call evil good and good evil,/_who present darkness as light and light as darkness,/_who make bitterness sweet and sweetness bitter.

17761.text: ¶Doom to those/who consider themselves wise,/_who think of themselves as clever.

17762.text: ¶Doom to the wine‑swigging warriors,/_mighty at mixing drinks,

17763.text: /_who spare the guilty for bribes,/_and rob the innocent of their rights.

17764.text: /Therefore, as a tongue of fire devours stubble,/_and as hay shrivels in a flame,/_so their roots will rot,/_and their blossoms turn to dust,/_for they have rejected the teaching of the Lord of heavenly forces,/_and have despised the word of Israel’s holy one.

17765.text: §¶This is why the Lord’s anger burned against the people:/_he extended his hand to strike them,/_the mountains trembled,/_and their corpses lay in the middle of the streets like dung./Even then God’s anger didn’t turn away;/_God’s hand was still extended.

17766.text: ¶God will raise a signal to a nation from far away/_and whistle to them from the end of the earth—/_now look—hurrying, swiftly they come!

17767.text: /Not one is tired; not one stumbles;/_they don’t rest or sleep;/_no belt is loose; no sandal broken;

17768.text: /_their arrows are sharp;/_all their bows drawn;/_their horses’ hooves are like flint;/_their wheels like the whirlwind.

17769.text: /_Their roaring is like the lion;/_they roar like young lions;/_they growl, seize their prey,/_and carry it off, with no one to rescue.

17770.text: /On that day, they will roar over it like the roaring of the sea./And if one looks toward the land, there’s darkness./_Tyre and the Nile will be darkened by the clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year of King Uzziah’s death, I saw the Lord sitting on a high and exalted throne, the edges of his robe filling the temple.

17772.text: Winged creatures were stationed around him. Each had six wings: with two they veiled their faces, with two their feet, and with two they flew about.

17773.text: They shouted to each other, saying:¶▼“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of heavenly forces!/All the earth is filled with God’s glory!”

17774.text: ¶The doorframe shook at the sound of their shouting, and the house was filled with smoke.

17775.text: ¶I said, “Mourn for me; I’m ruined! I’m a man with unclean lips, and I live among a people with unclean lips. Yet I’ve seen the king, the Lord of heavenly forces!”

17776.text: ¶Then one of the winged creatures flew to me, holding a glowing coal that he had taken from the altar with tongs.

17777.text: He touched my mouth and said, “See, this has touched your lips. Your guilt has departed, and your sin is removed.”

17778.text: ¶Then I heard the Lord’s voice saying, “Whom should I send, and who will go for us?”¶I said, “I’m here; send me.”

17779.text: ¶God said, “Go and say to this people:¶▼Listen intently, but don’t understand;/_look carefully, but don’t comprehend.

17780.text: /Make the minds of this people dull./_Make their ears deaf and their eyes blind,/_so they can’t see with their eyes/_or hear with their ears,/_or understand with their minds,/_and turn, and be healed.”

17781.text: ¶I said, “How long, Lord?”¶And God said, “Until cities lie ruined with no one living in them, until there are houses without people and the land is left devastated.”

17782.text: The Lord will send the people far away, and the land will be completely abandoned.

17783.text: Even if one‑tenth remain there, they will be burned again, like a terebinth or an oak, which when it is cut down leaves a stump. Its stump is a holy seed.

17784.text: §¶In the days of Ahaz (Jotham’s son and grandson of Judah’s King Uzziah), Aram’s King Rezin and Israel’s King Pekah (Remaliah’s son) came up to attack Jerusalem, but they couldn’t overpower it.

17785.text: ¶When the house of David was told that Aram had become allies with Ephraim, their hearts and the hearts of their people shook as the trees of a forest shake when there is a wind.

17786.text: But the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear‑jashub, at the end of the channel of the Upper Pool, by the road to the field where laundry is washed,

17787.text: and say to him, ‘Be careful and stay calm. Don’t fear, and don’t lose heart over these two pieces of smoking torches, over the burning anger of Rezin, Aram, and Remaliah’s son.

17788.text: Aram has planned evil against you with Ephraim and Remaliah’s son, saying,

17789.text: “Let’s march up against Judah, tear it apart, capture it for ourselves, and install Tabeel’s son as its king.”

17790.text: But the Lord God says: It won’t happen; it won’t take place.

17791.text: The chief of Aram is Damascus; the chief of Damascus is Rezin (in sixty‑five more years Ephraim will be shattered as a nation);

17792.text: the chief of Ephraim is Samaria; and the chief of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you don’t believe this, you can’t be trusted.’”

17794.text: “Ask a sign from the Lord your God. Make it as deep as the grave or as high as heaven.”

17795.text: ¶But Ahaz said, “I won’t ask; I won’t test the Lord.”

17796.text: ¶Then Isaiah said, “Listen, house of David! Isn’t it enough for you to be tiresome for people that you are also tiresome before my God?

17797.text: Therefore, the Lord will give you a sign. The young woman is pregnant and is about to give birth to a son, and she will name him Immanuel.

17798.text: He will eat butter and honey, and learn to reject evil and choose good.

17799.text: Before the boy learns to reject evil and choose good, the land of the two kings you dread will be abandoned.

17800.text: The Lord will bring upon you, upon your people, and upon your families days unlike any that have come since the day Ephraim broke away from Judah—the king of Assyria.”

17801.text: §¶On that day, the Lord will whistle for the flies from the remotest streams of Egypt and for the bees that are in the land of Assyria.

17802.text: They will come and settle in the steep ravines, in the cracks of the cliffs, in all the thornbushes, and in all the watering holes.

17803.text: ¶On that day, the Lord will shave with a razor hired from beyond the Euphrates—with the king of Assyria—the head and the pubic hair, and will cut off the beard as well.

17804.text: ¶On that day, one will raise a young cow and two sheep

17805.text: and will eat butter because of the abundance of milk, for all who remain in the land will eat butter and honey.

17806.text: ¶On that day, there will be thorns and thistles in every place where a thousand vines worth a thousand silver shekels once grew.

17807.text: Only those with bows and arrows will go there, because the entire land will become thorns and thistles.

17808.text: As for the hills that were once farmed with hoes, you won’t go there for fear of the thorns and thistles. They will become places where cattle are turned loose and sheep wander.

17809.text: §¶The Lord said to me, “Take a large tablet, and write on it in ordinary letters, For Maher‑shalal‑hash‑baz.

17810.text: Summon trusted people, Uriah the priest and Zechariah, Jeberechiah’s son, to witness it.”

17811.text: ¶I then had sex with the prophetess, and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher‑shalal‑hash‑baz.

17812.text: Before the boy knows how to say ‘my father’ and ‘my mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried away before the king of Assyria.”

17814.text: Since this people has rejected the waters of Shiloah that flow gently, and instead rejoices over Rezin and Remaliah’s son—

17815.text: therefore, look, the Lord is raising up against them the powerful floodwaters of the Euphrates, the king of Assyria and all his glory. It will rise up over all its channels, overflowing all its banks,

17816.text: and sweep into Judah, flooding, overflowing, and reaching up to the neck. But God is with us; the span of his wings will cover the width of the land.

17817.text: ¶Unite yourselves, peoples, and be shattered!/_Listen, all distant places of the earth!/Prepare to be shattered!/_Prepare to be shattered!

17818.text: /Create a plan, but be frustrated!/_Speak a word, but it won’t stand, for God is with us.

17819.text: ¶The Lord spoke to me, taking hold of me and warning me not to walk in the way of this people:

17820.text: Don’t call conspiracy all that this people calls conspiracy. Don’t fear what they fear, and don’t be terrified.

17821.text: It is the Lord of heavenly forces whom you should hold sacred, whom you should fear, and whom you should hold in awe.

17822.text: ¶God will become a sanctuary—/_but he will be a stone to trip over and a rock to stumble on for the two houses of Israel;/_a trap and a snare for those living in Jerusalem.

17823.text: /Many of them will stumble and fall,/_and be broken, snared, and captured.

17824.text: ¶Bind up the testimony; seal up the teaching among my disciples.

17825.text: I will wait for the Lord, who has hidden his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in God.

17826.text: Look! I and the children the Lord gave me are signs and wonders in Israel from the Lord of heavenly forces, who lives on Mount Zion.

17827.text: ¶If they say to you: “Consult the ghosts and the spirits that chirp and mutter. (Shouldn’t a people consult its gods?) Consult the dead on behalf of the living

17828.text: for instruction and for testimony”—they will surely say such things, but they will never see the dawn.

17829.text: ¶They will pass through the land, dejected and hungry, and when they are hungry, they will be enraged and will curse their king and God. They will turn toward heaven

17830.text: and look to the earth, but they will see only distress and darkness, random movement, and the anguish and doom of banishment.

17831.text: §¶Nonetheless, those who were in distress won’t be exhausted. At an earlier time, God cursed the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but later he glorified the way of the sea, the far side of the Jordan, and the Galilee of the nations.

17832.text: ¶The people walking in darkness have seen a great light./_On those living in a pitch‑dark land, light has dawned.

17833.text: /You have made the nation great;/_you have increased its joy./They rejoiced before you as with joy at the harvest,/_as those who divide plunder rejoice.

17834.text: /As on the day of Midian, you’ve shattered the yoke that burdened them,/_the staff on their shoulders,/_and the rod of their oppressor.

17835.text: /Because every boot of the thundering warriors,/_and every garment rolled in blood/_will be burned, fuel for the fire.

17836.text: /A child is born to us, a son is given to us,/_and authority will be on his shoulders./_He will be named/_Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,/_Eternal Father, Prince of Peace.

17837.text: /There will be vast authority and endless peace/_for David’s throne and for his kingdom,/_establishing and sustaining it/_with justice and righteousness/_now and forever.¶►The zeal of the Lord of heavenly forces will do this.

17838.text: §¶The Lord sent a word against Jacob;/_it fell upon Israel;

17839.text: /_the people all knew it—/_Ephraim and the one who rules in Samaria./But with a proud and arrogant heart they said,

17840.text: /_“Bricks have fallen,/_but let’s rebuild with stones./_Sycamores were cut down,/_but let’s replace them with cedars.”

17841.text: /So the Lord raised up their foes against them,/_and stirred up their enemies—

17842.text: /_Aram from the east and the Philistines from the west—/_and they devoured Israel with an open mouth./Even then God’s anger didn’t turn away;/_God’s hand was still extended.

17843.text: ¶But the people didn’t turn to the one who struck them./_They didn’t seek the Lord of heavenly forces.

17844.text: /So the Lord cut off head and tail,/_palm branch and reed from Israel in one day.

17845.text: /_(Elders and celebrities are the head;/_prophets who teach lies are the tail.)

17846.text: /But this people’s leaders were misleading,/_and those being led were confused.

17847.text: /So the Lord showed their youth no pity,/_and showed their orphans and widows no mercy;/_for everyone was godless and evil;/_every mouth spoke nonsense./Even then God’s anger didn’t turn away;/_God’s hand was still extended.

17848.text: ¶Wickedness burned like fire,/_devouring thorn and thistle./It kindled the thickets of the forest;/_they swirled in rising smoke.

17849.text: /The land was scorched by the rage of the Lord of heavenly forces;/_the people were like fuel for the fire./Not one person pitied another:

17850.text: /_they consumed on the right, but remained hungry;/_devoured on the left, and weren’t satisfied./_They devoured the flesh of their own children.

17851.text: /Manasseh devoured Ephraim and Ephraim Manasseh;/_together they turned against Judah./Even then God’s anger didn’t turn away;/_God’s hand was still extended.

17852.text: §¶Doom to those who pronounce wicked decrees,/_and keep writing harmful laws

17853.text: /_to deprive the needy of their rights/_and to rob the poor among my people of justice;/_to make widows their loot;/_to steal from orphans!

17854.text: /What will you do on the day of punishment/_when disaster comes from far away?/To whom will you flee for help;/_where will you stash your wealth?

17855.text: /How will you avoid crouching among the prisoners/_and falling among the slain?/Even so, God’s anger hasn’t turned away;/_God’s hand is still extended.

17856.text: §¶Doom to Assyria, rod of my anger,/_in whose hand is the staff of my fury!

17857.text: /Against a godless nation I send him;/_against an infuriating people/_I direct him to seize spoil, to steal plunder,/_and to trample them like mud in the streets.

17858.text: /But he has other plans;/_he schemes in secret;/_destruction is on his mind,/_extermination of nation after nation.

17859.text: /He says: Aren’t my commanders all kings?

17860.text: /_Isn’t Calno like Carchemish?/_Isn’t Hamath like Arpad?/_Isn’t Samaria like Damascus?

17861.text: /Just as I took control of idolatrous kingdoms/_with more images than Jerusalem and Samaria,

17862.text: /_just as I did to Samaria and her false gods,/_won’t I also do this to Jerusalem and her idols?

17863.text: ¶But when the Lord has finished all this work on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, he will punish the Assyrian king’s arrogant actions and the boasting of his haughty eyes.

17864.text: ¶He said, “By my own strength I have achieved it,/_and by my wisdom, since I’m so clever./_I disregarded national boundaries; I raided their treasures;/_I knocked down their rulers like a bull.

17865.text: /_My hand found the wealth of the peoples/_as if it were in a nest./Just as one gathers abandoned eggs,/_I have gathered the entire earth;/_no creature fluttered a wing or opened a mouth to chirp.”

17866.text: ¶Will the ax glorify itself over the one who chops with it?/_Or will the saw magnify itself over its user?/As if a rod could wave the one who lifts it!/_As if a staff could lift up the one not made of wood!

17867.text: /Therefore, the Lord God of heavenly forces/_will make the well‑fed people waste away;/_and among his officials,/_a blaze will burn like scorching fire.

17868.text: /The light of Israel will become a fire,/_its holy one a flame,/_which will burn and devour/_its thorns and thistles/_in a single day.

17869.text: /Its abundant forest and farmland/_will be finished completely,/_as when a sick person wastes away;

17870.text: /_its forest’s remaining trees will be no more than a child can count.

17871.text: §¶On that day, what’s left of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no longer depend on the one who beat them. Instead, they will faithfully depend on the Lord, the holy one of Israel.

17872.text: A few will return, what’s left of Jacob, to the mighty God.

17873.text: Although your people, Israel, were like the sand of the sea, only a few survivors will return. The end is announced, overflowing with justice.

17874.text: Yes, destruction has been announced; the Lord God of heavenly forces will carry it out against the entire land.

17875.text: ¶Therefore, the Lord God of heavenly forces says: My people who live in Zion, don’t fear Assyria, which strikes you with the rod and raises its staff against you as Egypt did.

17876.text: In a very short time my fury will end, and my anger at the world will be finished.

17877.text: ¶Therefore, the Lord of heavenly forces will crack a whip against Assyria,/_as when he struck Midian at the rock of Oreb./_He will raise a rod over the sea,/_as he did in Egypt.

17878.text: /On that day, God will remove the burden from your shoulder/_and destroy the yoke on your neck.§¶He has gone up from Samaria,

17879.text: /_come against Aiath,/_passed to Migron./At Michmash he stored his equipment.

17880.text: /They crossed at the pass: “We’ll camp at Geba!”/_Ramah trembles; Gibeah of Saul has fled.

17881.text: /Cry aloud, Daughter Gallim!/_Listen, Laishah! Answer her, Anathoth!

17883.text: /This very day he will stand at Nob/_and shake his fist at Daughter Zion’s mountain,/_the hill of Jerusalem!

17884.text: /Look! The Lord God of heavenly forces/_is chopping off the branches with terrible power./_The loftiest ones are about to be cut down/_and the exalted laid low.

17885.text: /He will strike down the forest thickets with an ax,/_and mighty Lebanon will fall.

17886.text: §¶A shoot will grow up from the stump of Jesse;/_a branch will sprout from his roots.

17887.text: /The Lord’s spirit will rest upon him,/_a spirit of wisdom and understanding,/_a spirit of planning and strength,/_a spirit of knowledge and fear of the Lord.

17888.text: /He will delight in fearing the Lord./He won’t judge by appearances,/_nor decide by hearsay.

17889.text: /He will judge the needy with righteousness,/_and decide with equity for those who suffer in the land./He will strike the violent with the rod of his mouth;/_by the breath of his lips he will kill the wicked.

17890.text: /Righteousness will be the belt around his hips,/_and faithfulness the belt around his waist.

17891.text: /The wolf will live with the lamb,/_and the leopard will lie down with the young goat;/_the calf and the young lion will feed together,/_and a little child will lead them.

17892.text: /The cow and the bear will graze./_Their young will lie down together,/_and a lion will eat straw like an ox.

17893.text: /A nursing child will play over the snake’s hole;/_toddlers will reach right over the serpent’s den.

17894.text: /They won’t harm or destroy anywhere on my holy mountain./_The earth will surely be filled with the knowledge of the Lord,/_just as the water covers the sea.

17895.text: §¶On that day, the root of Jesse will stand as a signal to the peoples. The nations will seek him out, and his dwelling will be glorious.

17896.text: ¶On that day, the Lord will extend his hand a second time to reclaim the survivors of God’s people who are left from Assyria and from Egypt, from Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and from the coastlands of the sea.

17897.text: ¶God will raise a signal for the nations and gather the outcast men of Israel./_God will collect the dispersed women of Judah from the four corners of the earth.

17898.text: /Ephraim’s jealousy will cease,/_and Judah’s harassment will be eliminated./Ephraim won’t be jealous of Judah,/_and Judah won’t harass Ephraim.

17899.text: /But they will swoop down on the slopes of Philistia to the west;/_together they will plunder the people to the east./Edom and Moab will be under their power,/_and the Ammonites will be their subjects.

17900.text: ¶The Lord will split the tongue of the Egyptian sea. God will wave a hand over the Euphrates with a powerful wind and break it into seven streams so that it can be crossed in sandals.

17901.text: Then there will be a highway from Assyria for the survivors of God’s people who are left from Assyria, just as there was for Israel on the day they went up from the land of Egypt.

17902.text: §¶You will say on that day:/“I thank you, Lord./Though you were angry with me,/_your anger turned away and you comforted me.

17903.text: /God is indeed my salvation;/_I will trust and won’t be afraid./Yah, the Lord, is my strength and my shield;/_he has become my salvation.”

17904.text: ¶You will draw water with joy from the springs of salvation.

17905.text: /And you will say on that day:/“Thank the Lord; call on God’s name;/_proclaim God’s deeds among the peoples;/_declare that God’s name is exalted.

17906.text: /Sing to the Lord, who has done glorious things;/_proclaim this throughout all the earth.”

17907.text: /Shout and sing for joy, city of Zion,/_because the holy one of Israel is great among you.

17908.text: §¶An oracle about Babylon, which Isaiah, Amoz’s son, saw.

17909.text: ¶On a bare mountain raise a signal;/_cry aloud to them;/_wave a hand;/_let them enter the officials’ gates.

17910.text: /I have commanded my holy ones;/_I have called my warriors,/_my proud, jubilant ones,/_to execute my wrath.

17911.text: /Listen! A roar on the mountains like that of a great crowd./Listen! An uproar of kingdoms,/_of nations coming together./The Lord of heavenly forces is mustering an army for battle.

17912.text: /They are coming from a distant land,/_from the faraway heavens,/_the Lord and the instruments of his fury, to destroy the whole land.

17913.text: ¶Wail, for the day of the Lord is near./_Like destruction from the Almighty it will come.

17914.text: /Then all hands will fall limp;/_every human heart will melt,

17915.text: /_and they will be terrified./Like a woman writhing in labor,/_they will be seized by spasms and agony./They will look at each other aghast,/_their faces blazing.

17916.text: ¶Look, the day of the Lord is coming with cruel rage and burning anger,/_making the earth a ruin,/_and wiping out its sinners.

17917.text: /Heaven’s stars and constellations won’t show their light./The sun will be dark when it rises;/_the moon will no longer shine.

17918.text: /I will bring disaster upon the world for its evil,/_and bring their own sin upon the wicked./I will end the pride of the insolent,/_and the conceit of tyrants I will lay low.

17919.text: /I will make humans scarcer than fine gold;/_people rarer than the gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /I will rattle the heavens;/_the earth will shake loose from its place—because of the rage/_of the Lord of heavenly forces/_on the day his anger burns.

17921.text: /They will be like hunted gazelles, like sheep without a shepherd;/_all will turn to their own people/_and flee to their own lands.

17922.text: /Whoever is found will be stabbed;/_whoever is caught will fall by the sword.

17923.text: /Their infants will be crushed before their eyes;/_their houses plundered, their women raped.

17924.text: ¶Look! I’m rousing the Medes against them;/_the Medes pay no mind to silver, no desire for gold.

17925.text: /Their bows will smash youths;/_they will be merciless to newborns, pitiless to children.

17926.text: /So Babylon, a jewel among kingdoms,/_the Chaldeans’ splendor and pride,/_will be like Sodom and Gomorrah,/_destroyed by God.

17927.text: /No one will ever resettle/_or live there for generations./No Arab will camp there;/_no shepherds will rest flocks there.

17928.text: /Wildcats will rest there;/_houses will be filled with owls./Ostriches will live there,/_and goat demons will dance there.

17929.text: /Hyenas will howl in its strongholds,/_and jackals in its luxurious palaces./Babylon’s time is coming soon;/_its days won’t drag on.

17930.text: §¶The Lord will have compassion on Jacob, will again choose Israel, and will give them rest in their own land. Immigrants will join them, and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.

17931.text: The peoples will take them and will bring them to their own place. The house of Israel will possess them as male and female slaves in the Lord’s land, making captives of their captors and ruling their oppressors.

17932.text: §¶When the Lord has given you rest from pain and trouble and from the hard labor that you perform,

17933.text: you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon:¶▼How the oppressor has ceased!/_How the flood has receded!

17934.text: /The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,/_the rod of tyrants

17935.text: /_that struck peoples in rage with ceaseless blows,/_that ruled nations with anger,/_with relentless aggression.

17936.text: ¶All the earth rests quietly,/_then it breaks into song.

17937.text: /Even the cypresses rejoice over you,/_the cedars of Lebanon:/_“Since you were laid low,/_no logger comes up against us!”

17938.text: ¶The underworld beneath becomes restless to greet your arrival./It awakens the ghosts,/_all the leaders of earth;/it makes the kings of the nations rise from their thrones.

17939.text: /All of them speak and say to you:/_“Even you’ve become weak like we are!/_You are the same as us!”

17940.text: /Your majesty has been brought down to the underworld,/_along with the sound of your harps./Under you is a bed of maggots,/_and worms are your blanket.

17941.text: ¶How you’ve fallen from heaven,/_morning star, son of dawn!/You are cut down to earth,/_helpless on your back!

17942.text: /You said to yourself, I will climb up to heaven;/_above God’s stars, I will raise my throne./I’ll sit on the mount of assembly,/_on the heights of Zaphon.

17943.text: /I’ll go up to the cloud tops;/_I’ll be like the Most High!

17944.text: /But down to the underworld you are brought,/_to the depths of the pit.

17945.text: ¶Those who see you will stare at you;/_they will examine you closely:/_“Is this the man who rattled the earth,/_who shook kingdoms,

17946.text: /_who made the world a wasteland/_and tore down its cities,/_and wouldn’t let his prisoners go home?”

17947.text: /All the kings of the nations lie down honored,/_all of them, each in his own tomb.

17948.text: /_But you are cast away from your own grave/_like a rejected branch,/_covered by the dead/_and those pierced by the sword—/_who go down to the stony pit—/_like a trampled corpse.

17949.text: /You won’t join them in burial,/_for you destroyed your own land;/_you killed your own people./Such evil offspring will never be mentioned again!

17950.text: ¶Prepare a place to slaughter his sons for the guilt of their father. Don’t let them arise to take over the earth or fill the world with cities.

17951.text: ¶I will arise against them, says the Lord of heavenly forces. I will cut off Babylon’s renown and remnant, offshoot and offspring.

17952.text: I will make it the home of herons, a swampland. I will sweep it away with the broom of destruction, says the Lord of heavenly forces.

17953.text: §¶The Lord of heavenly forces has promised:/As I intended, so it will be;/_and as I have planned, so it will happen:

17954.text: /I will break Assyria in my land;/_on my mountains I will trample it/_and remove its yoke from my people;/_his burden will be taken from their shoulders.

17955.text: /This is the plan that has been made for all the earth;/_this is the hand extended over all the nations.

17956.text: /The Lord of heavenly forces has created a plan;/_who can stop it?/God’s hand is extended;/_who will stop it?

17957.text: §¶This oracle came in the year of King Ahaz’s death:

17958.text: ¶Don’t rejoice, all you Philistines, that the rod that struck you is broken,/_because from the snake’s root a viper will grow,/_and it will produce a winged creature.

17959.text: /The oldest offspring of the poor will graze;/_their needy will lie down secure./But he will starve your offspring to death,/_and murder all who remain.

17960.text: /Wail, gate! Cry out, city!/_Melt in terror, all you Philistines!/_Smoke is coming from the north;/_there is no straggler in its ranks.

17961.text: /What will one say to that nation’s messengers?/_The Lord has founded Zion;/_the oppressed among God’s people will find refuge there.

17962.text: §¶An oracle about Moab.¶▼Ar was devastated in a night; Moab is ruined!/_Kir was devastated in a night; Moab is ruined!

17963.text: /Dibon has gone up to the temple, to the shrines to weep./Moab wails over Nebo and over Medeba./_Every head is shaved,/_every beard cut off.

17964.text: /In its streets they wear mourning clothes;/_on its rooftops and in its plazas, everyone wails and falls down weeping.

17965.text: /Heshbon and Elealeh cry out;/_as far as Jahaz their voice is heard./The armed men of Moab shout,/_spirits trembling.

17966.text: /My heart cries out for Moab./_Its fugitives flee to Zoar, to Eglath‑shelishiyah./At the ascent of Luhith,/_each will go up with weeping./On the road to Horonaim,/_they will raise a piercing cry.

17967.text: /The waters of Nimrim are used up./_Grass has withered;/_vegetation is dead;/_greenery is gone.

17968.text: /Therefore, they carry what they had stored up,/_all their provisions to the Valley of the Willows.

17969.text: /An outcry sounds within the borders of Moab,/_as far as Eglaim, a cry of distress,/_as far as Beer‑elim, a cry of distress.

17970.text: /The waters of Dibon are full of blood./_But I will bring still more upon Dibon:/_a lion for Moab’s survivors, for the remaining few in the land.

17971.text: ¶Send lambs to the ruler of the land,/_from Sela through the desert/_to the mountain of Daughter Zion.

17972.text: /The daughters of Moab at the fords of the Arnon are like orphaned birds pushed from the nest.

17973.text: /Consider carefully, act justly;/_at high noon provide your shade like night./Hide the outcasts;/_keep the fugitives hidden.

17974.text: /Let the outcasts of Moab live among you./_Be a hiding place for them from the destroyer./When the oppressor is no more,/_when destruction has ceased,/_when the trampler has vanished from the land,

17975.text: /_a throne will be established based on goodness,/_and someone will sit faithfully on it in David’s dwelling—/_a judge who seeks justice and timely righteousness.

17976.text: ¶We have heard of Moab’s pride,/_his great pride,/_his outrageous pride and arrogance,/_his empty boasting.

17977.text: /Therefore, let Moab wail;/_let everyone wail for Moab./_Let them moan, utterly stricken, for the raisin cakes of Kir‑hareseth.

17978.text: /The fields of Heshbon languish./_The vines of Sibmah,/_whose honored grapes overpowered masters of nations,/_had reached as far as Jazer and strayed to the desert./_Their tendrils spread out and crossed the sea.

17979.text: /Therefore, I will weep with Jazer’s weeping for the vines of Sibmah./_I will drench you with my tears, Heshbon and Elealeh./Cheers have fallen silent concerning your summer fruit and your grain harvest.

17980.text: /Joy and happiness have been harvested from the farmland,/_and in the vineyards no one sings, no one shouts./No treader crushes grapes in the wine vats;/_I have brought the cheers to an end.

17981.text: /Therefore, my heart plays sadly like a harp for Moab,/_my inner being for Kir‑heres.

17982.text: /Even if Moab presents himself,/_and Moab wears himself out going to the shrine,/_and comes to his sanctuary to pray,/_he won’t prevail.

17983.text: ¶This is the word that the Lord had spoken concerning Moab long ago.

17984.text: But now the Lord has said: In three years, like the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moab, with all its great multitude, will dwindle. The small remnant will be few and feeble.

17985.text: §¶An oracle about Damascus.¶▼Look! Damascus is finished as a city;/_it will become a fallen ruin.

17986.text: /The villages of Aroer are abandoned forever./_They will be pastures for flocks,/_which will lie down undisturbed.

17987.text: /Ephraim’s security will cease,/_as will Damascus’ rule./_What’s left of Aram will resemble the glory of the Israelites,/_says the Lord of heavenly forces.

17988.text: ¶On that day, Jacob’s glory will dwindle;/_his sleek body will waste away.

17989.text: /It will be as when harvesters gather grain./_God will harvest armfuls at a time,/_like one who gathers grain/_in the Rephaim Valley.

17990.text: /Only remaining bits are left,/_like an olive tree that has been shaken:/_two or three olives on the highest branch;/_four or five on a fruitful twig,/_says the Lord God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶On that day, people will have regard for their maker,/_and their eyes will look to the holy one of Israel.

17992.text: /They will have no regard for altars,/_the work of their hands,/_or look to what their fingers made:/_sacred poles and incense stands.

17993.text: ¶On that day, their strong cities will be like those abandoned by the Hivites and the Amorites; abandoned because of the Israelites. They will be a wasteland,

17994.text: ¶because you forgot the God who saves you,/_and didn’t remember the rock who shelters you./Therefore, plant your pleasant plants,/_and set out exotic sprouts;

17995.text: /_make them grow the day you plant them,/_and make them bloom the morning you start them./But the harvest will disappear on a day of sickness and incurable pain.

17996.text: ¶Doom to the raging of many peoples;/_like the thundering seas they thunder./_Doom to the roar of nations,/_like the roaring of mighty waters.

17997.text: /_Nations roar like the roaring of rushing waters./But God will rebuke them,/_and they will flee far away,/_pursued like chaff by wind in the mountains,/_like tumbleweeds before a storm.

17998.text: /In the evening, there is terror;/_but before morning it is gone./This is the fate of those who loot us,/_the destiny of those who rob us.

17999.text: §¶Doom to the land of winged ships,/_beyond the rivers of Cush

18000.text: /_that sends messengers by sea,/_reed vessels on the water./Go, swift messengers,/_to a nation tall and clean‑shaven,/_to a people feared near and far,/_a nation barbaric and oppressive,/_whose land the rivers divide.

18001.text: ¶All you who inhabit the world,/_who live on earth,/_when a signal is raised on the mountains, you will see!/_When the trumpet blasts, you will hear!

18002.text: /The Lord said to me:/_I will quietly watch from my own place,/_like the shimmering heat of sunshine,/_like a cloud’s shade in the harvest heat.

18003.text: /Before the harvest, when the bloom is finished, when the blossom is becoming/a ripening fruit,/_God will cut the shoots with a pruning knife,/_and lop off the spreading branches.

18004.text: /_They will all be left to the mountain birds/_and to the beasts of the land./_The birds will eat them in summer,/_all the beasts of the land in winter.

18005.text: ¶At that time, gifts will be brought to the Lord of heavenly forces/_from a tall and clean‑shaven people/_and from a people feared near and far,/_a nation barbaric and oppressive,/_whose land the rivers divide,/_to the place of the name of the Lord of heavenly forces,/_to Mount Zion.

18006.text: §¶An oracle about Egypt.¶▼Look! The Lord is riding upon a swift cloud,/_and is coming to Egypt./Egypt’s idols will tremble before God;/_the Egyptians’ hearts will melt within them.

18007.text: /I will stir up Egyptian against Egyptian,/_and they will fight,/_one against another,/_neighbor against neighbor,/_city against city,/_kingdom against kingdom.

18008.text: /Egypt’s spirit will fail from within;/_I will frustrate their plans./_They will consult the idols and spirits/_and ghosts and fortune‑tellers.

18009.text: /I will hand Egypt over to a harsh master;/_a strong king will rule them, says the Lord God of heavenly forces.

18010.text: ¶The waters of the sea will dry up;/_the river will be parched and bare.

18011.text: /The rivers will stink;/_the streams will shrink and dry;/_reeds and rushes will decay.

18012.text: /Grass around the Nile, the grass at the mouth of the Nile,/_and all the sown land of the Nile/_will dry up, blow away, and be no more.

18013.text: /Those who fish will lament;/_all who cast fishhooks in the Nile will mourn,/_and those who spread nets on the water will pine away.

18014.text: /Workers with flax will be dismayed;/_carders and weavers will grow pale.

18015.text: /Makers of cloth will be crushed;/_all who earn money will become distressed.

18016.text: ¶The officials of Tanis are fools;/_the wisest of Pharaoh’s counselors give stupid advice./How can you say to Pharaoh,/_“I’m a wise person,/_one of the ancient kings”?

18017.text: /Where now are your wise ones?/_Let them tell you,/_let them inform you what the Lord of heavenly forces has planned concerning Egypt.

18018.text: /The officials of Tanis have become fools;/_the princes of Memphis are deluded;/_the tribal chiefs have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /_The Lord has poured into them a spirit of confusion./_They will make Egypt stumble in everything it does,/_just as a drunk stumbles in his vomit.

18020.text: /Neither head nor tail, palm branch nor reed/_will be able to do anything for Egypt.

18021.text: §¶On that day, the Egyptians will be like women and will tremble with terror before the hand that the Lord of heavenly forces will raise against them.

18022.text: Judah’s land will become what the Egyptians dread; whenever anyone mentions it, they will be terrified because of the plans that the Lord of heavenly forces is making against them.

18023.text: ¶On that day, there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak the language of Canaan and swear loyalty to the Lord of heavenly forces. One of them will be called “the city of the sun.”

18024.text: ¶On that day, there will be an altar to the Lord within the land of Egypt, and a standing stone for the Lord at its border.

18025.text: It will be a sign and a witness to the Lord of heavenly forces in the land of Egypt. When they cry out to the Lord because of oppressors, God will send them a savior and defender to rescue them.

18026.text: The Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians; the Egyptians will know the Lord on that day. They will worship with sacrifices and offerings, making solemn promises to the Lord and fulfilling them.

18027.text: The Lord will strike Egypt; striking and then healing. They will return to the Lord, who will hear their pleas and heal them.

18028.text: ¶On that day, there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria. The Assyrians will come to Egypt, and the Egyptians to Assyria; and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.

18029.text: ¶On that day, Israel will be the third along with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing at the center of the world.

18030.text: The Lord of heavenly forces will pronounce this blessing: Bless Egypt my people, and Assyria my handiwork, and Israel my inheritance.

18031.text: §¶In the year that Assyria’s King Sargon sent his general to Ashdod, he fought against Ashdod and captured it.

18032.text: At that time the Lord had spoken through Isaiah, Amoz’s son, “Go, take off the mourning clothes from your waist, and remove the shoes from your feet.” And Isaiah did this, walking naked and barefoot.

18033.text: ¶The Lord said, “Just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot three years, as a sign and omen against Egypt and Cush,

18034.text: so will the king of Assyria lead the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, both young and old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks bared, humiliating Egypt.

18035.text: They will be shattered and shamed because of Cush their hope, and because of Egypt their glory.

18036.text: ¶“On that day, those who live on this coast will say, ‘Look at those in whom we had hoped, to whom we fled for help and rescue from the king of Assyria. How then will we escape?’”

18037.text: §¶An oracle about the wilderness near the sea.¶▼Like whirlwinds sweeping through the arid southern plain,/_it comes from the desert, from a fearsome land.

18038.text: /A harsh vision was proclaimed to me:/_The betrayer betrays, and the destroyer destroys./Go up, Elam! Lay siege, Media!/_Put an end to all her groaning.

18039.text: /Therefore, I’m shaken to my core in anguish./_Pains have seized me like the pains of a woman in labor./I’m too bent over to hear,/_too dismayed to see.

18040.text: /My heart pounds; convulsions overpower me./_He has turned my evening of pleasure into dread—

18041.text: /_setting the table, spreading the cloth, eating, drinking./“Arise, captains!/_Polish the shields.”

18042.text: ¶The Lord said this to me:/_“Go, post a lookout to report what he sees.

18043.text: /When he sees chariots, pairs of horsemen,/_donkey riders, camel riders,/_he should listen carefully,/_carefully, very carefully.”

18044.text: ¶Then the seer called out:/“Upon a watchtower, Lord,/_I’m standing all day;/_and upon my observation post/_I’m stationed throughout the night.

18045.text: /Here they come:/_charioteers, pairs of horsemen!”/One spoke up and said,/_“Fallen, fallen is Babylon,/_and all the images of her gods/_are shattered on the ground!”

18046.text: /Oh, my downtrodden people, threshed on my threshing floor,/_what I heard from the Lord of heavenly forces,/_the God of Israel, I reported to you.

18047.text: §¶An oracle about Dumah.¶▼Someone is calling to me from Seir:/_“Guard, how long is the night?/_Guard, how long is the night?”

18048.text: /The guard said,/_“Morning has come, but it is still night./_If you must inquire, inquire;/_come back again.”

18049.text: ¶An oracle about the desert./In the woods, in the desert where you camp,/_caravans of the Dedanites

18050.text: /_meet the thirsty with water;/_inhabitants of the land of Tema greet the refugees with bread.

18051.text: /They have fled from swords,/_from the drawn sword,/_from the bent bow/_and from the intensity of battle.

18052.text: ¶So the Lord said to me: Within a year, according to the number of years for which a laborer is hired, all the glory of Kedar will end;

18053.text: there will be few Kedarite archers remaining. The Lord God of Israel has spoken.

18054.text: §¶An oracle about the Valley of Vision.¶▼What is wrong with you,/_that you have all gone up to the rooftops,

18055.text: /_you who are filled with noise,/_you roaring city, you party town?/Your dead weren’t slaughtered by the sword;/_they didn’t die in battle.

18056.text: /All your leaders escaped together/_but were captured without a single bow shot./_All your escapees were bound together, even though they fled far away.

18057.text: /Therefore, I said, “Don’t look at me;/_let me weep bitterly./_Don’t try to comfort me/_about the destruction of my dearly loved people.”

18058.text: /The Lord God of heavenly forces has a day of tumult and trampling and turmoil in the Valley of Vision,/_a breaking down of walls,/_a cry for help to the mountains.

18059.text: /Elam carried the quiver with chariots and horsemen,/_and Kir uncovered the shield.

18060.text: /Your finest valleys were filled with chariots,/_and horsemen doggedly guarded the gate.

18061.text: /Judah’s covering has been stripped away.¶On that day, you trusted the weapons in the Forest House.

18062.text: /_You observed the many broken defenses in David’s City,/_and you collected the waters of the lower pool.

18063.text: /You counted Jerusalem’s houses,/_and you tore down houses to fortify the wall.

18064.text: /You made a reservoir between the walls for the water of the earlier pool./_But you didn’t trust its maker;/_you didn’t consider the one who planned it long ago.

18065.text: ¶The Lord God of heavenly forces called on that day/_for weeping and mourning, and shaven heads, and wearing of mourning clothes.

18066.text: /But instead there was/_fun and frivolity,/_killing of cattle/_and slaughtering of sheep,/_eating of meat and drinking of wine:/_“Eat and drink! Tomorrow we will die!”

18067.text: /But the Lord of heavenly forces has revealed in my hearing:/_This iniquity won’t be forgiven you until you die, says the Lord God of heavenly forces.

18068.text: §¶The Lord God of heavenly forces says, Go now to this official, to Shebna, who is in charge of the house, and say to him:

18069.text: /_What do you have here—and whom do you have here—/_that you have hewed out a tomb for yourself,/_you who cuts his grave on high and carves himself a home in the cliff?

18070.text: /The Lord is about to hurl you down, mighty man!¶He is surely going to cover you with darkness;

18071.text: /_he will indeed unroll your head wrapping,/_rolling it like a ball into the open country./_There you will die, with your glorious chariots,/_you disgrace to the house of your master!

18072.text: /I will thrust you from your monument;/_you will be pulled down from your platform.

18073.text: /On that day, I will call my servant/_Eliakim, Hilkiah’s son.

18074.text: /I will give him your robe and wrap him in your sash,/_and I will hand over to him your authority./He will be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem/_and to the house of Judah.

18075.text: /I will place the key to David’s house on his shoulder;/_what he opens no one will close,/_and what he closes no one will open.

18076.text: /I will fasten him securely like a tent peg,/_and he will be a throne of honor for his ancestors’ house.

18077.text: ¶All the honor of his household will hang on him, the offspring and the offshoots, every little dish, every bowl, every jar.

18078.text: ¶On that day, says the Lord of heavenly forces, the peg that is fastened securely will give way; it will be cut down, and it will fall, and all the load hanging on it will be lost. The Lord has spoken.

18079.text: §¶An oracle about Tyre.¶▼Wail, ships of Tarshish,/_because your port is destroyed!/_When returning from Cyprus, they heard about it.

18080.text: /Be still, inhabitants of the coast, traders of Sidon,/_whose messengers crossed over the sea,

18081.text: /_over the mighty waters./The grain of Shihor, the Nile’s harvest, was her income;/_she was the marketplace of nations.

18082.text: /Be ashamed, Sidon, because the sea has spoken;/_the fortress of the sea has said,/_“I haven’t been in labor; I didn’t give birth;/_I never raised young men or brought up young women.”

18083.text: /When the Egyptians hear,/_they will be in anguish at the news about Tyre.

18084.text: /Cross over to Tarshish;/_wail, inhabitants of the coast.

18085.text: /Is this your triumphant town,/_whose origin is from ancient times,/_whose feet carried her to settle far away?

18086.text: /Who planned this concerning Tyre,/_the one who gives crowns,/_whose merchants were princes,/_whose traders were the honored of the earth?

18087.text: /The Lord of heavenly forces planned it,/_to defile the pride of all beauty,/_to shame all the honored of the earth.

18088.text: ¶Go through your own land, Daughter Tarshish,/_for the harbor is gone.

18089.text: /God’s hand is extended over the sea, shaking nations./The Lord gave the command to destroy Phoenicia’s fortresses,

18090.text: /_saying, You will no longer celebrate,/_violated virgin Daughter Sidon./Get up and head to Cyprus;/_even there you will find no rest.

18091.text: /Look at the land of the Chaldeans,/_the people who are no more./Assyria destined it for wild animals:/_they raised up their siege towers,/_stripped its palaces,/_and made it a ruin.

18092.text: /Wail, ships of Tarshish,/_for your fortress is destroyed!

18093.text: ¶On that day, Tyre will be forgotten seventy years, the lifetime of one king. At the end of seventy years, Tyre will become like the prostitute in the song:

18094.text: ¶Take a harp, go around the city, forgotten prostitute./_Play well, sing many songs, so they’ll remember you.

18095.text: ¶At the end of seventy years, the Lord will visit Tyre. She will return to her trade and will prostitute herself with all the kingdoms on the earth.

18096.text: Her profits and wages will be sacred to the Lord. They won’t be stored or saved. Her profits will go to those living before the Lord, for plentiful food and elegant clothes.

18097.text: §¶Look! The Lord will devastate the earth and destroy it,/_will twist its face and scatter its inhabitants.

18098.text: /It will be the same for the people and for the priest;/_for the slave and for his master;/_for the female servant and for her mistress;/_for the buyer and for the seller;/_for the lender and for the borrower;/_for the creditor and for the debtor.

18099.text: /The earth will be devastated, totally devastated;/_it will be destroyed, completely destroyed/_because the Lord has said it would be so.

18100.text: ¶The earth dries up and wilts;/_the world withers and wilts;/_the heavens wither away with the earth.

18101.text: /The earth lies polluted under its inhabitants,/_for they have disobeyed instruction,/_swept aside law,/_and broken the ancient covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore, a curse devours the earth; its inhabitants suffer for their guilt./Therefore, the earth’s inhabitants dwindle; very few are left.

18103.text: ¶The wine dries up;/_the vine withers;/_all the merry‑hearted groan.

18104.text: /The joyous tambourines have ceased;/_the roar of partyers has stopped;/_the joyous harp has ceased.

18105.text: /No one drinks wine or sings;/_beer is bitter to its drinkers.

18106.text: /The town is in chaos, broken;/_every house is shut, without entrance.

18107.text: /There is a cry for wine in the streets./_All joy has reached its dusk;/_happiness is exiled from the earth.

18108.text: /Ruin remains in the city,/_and the gate is battered to wreckage.

18109.text: /It will be like this in the central part of the land and among the peoples,/_like an olive tree that has been shaken,/_like remains from the grape harvest.

18110.text: ¶They raise their voice;/_they sing with joy;/_from the west they will shout about the Lord’s majesty.

18111.text: /Therefore, in the east honor the Lord;/_in the islands of the sea,/_the name of the Lord God of Israel!

18112.text: /From the ends of the earth we have heard songs:/_“Glory to the righteous one!”/But I say, “I waste away; I waste away;/_I’m doomed!/_Betrayers betray; treacherously betrayers betray.”

18113.text: ¶Terror, trench, and trap are upon you,/_ruler of the earth!

18114.text: /Whoever flees from the sound of terror will fall into the trench;/_whoever climbs from the trench will be caught in the trap.¶Heaven’s windows will open, and the earth’s foundations will quake.

18115.text: /The earth is shattering, shattering;/_the earth is shaking, shaking;/_the earth is teetering, tottering.

18116.text: /The earth trembles like a drunk/_and shudders like a hut;/_its rebellion weighs heavy upon it;/_it will fall, no more to rise.

18117.text: ¶On that day, the Lord will punish the forces of heaven in heaven, and the kings of the earth on earth.

18118.text: They will be gathered together like prisoners in a pit, shut into a prison, and punished after many days.

18119.text: The moon will be diminished, and the sun will fade, since the Lord of heavenly forces will rule on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, glorious before his elders.

18120.text: §¶Lord, you are my God./I will exalt you; I will praise your name,/_for you have done wonderful things,/_planned long ago, faithful and sure.

18121.text: /You have turned the city into rubble,/_the fortified town into a ruin,/_the fortress of foreigners into a city no more,/_never to be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Therefore, strong people will glorify you;/_the towns of tyrant nations will fear you.

18123.text: /You have been a refuge for the poor,/_a refuge for the needy in distress,/_a hiding place from the storm,/_a shade from the heat./When the breath of tyrants is like a winter storm

18124.text: /_or like heat in the desert,/_you subdue the roar of foreigners./Like heat shaded by a cloud,/_the tyrants’ song falls silent.

18125.text: ¶On this mountain,/_the Lord of heavenly forces will prepare for all peoples/_a rich feast, a feast of choice wines,/_of select foods rich in flavor,/_of choice wines well refined.

18126.text: /He will swallow up on this mountain the veil that is veiling all peoples,/_the shroud enshrouding all nations.

18127.text: /He will swallow up death forever./The Lord God will wipe tears from every face;/_he will remove his people’s disgrace from off the whole earth,/_for the Lord has spoken.

18128.text: /They will say on that day,/“Look! This is our God,/_for whom we have waited—/_and he has saved us!/This is the Lord, for whom we have waited;/_let’s be glad and rejoice in his salvation!”

18129.text: /_The Lord’s hand will indeed rest on this mountain.¶Moab will be trampled down/_as straw is trampled into manure.

18130.text: /When in it they spread out their hands/_as swimmers spread out their hands to swim,/_God will lay low their pride, even by the efforts of their hands.

18131.text: /The fortified towers of their walls will be thrown down,/will be leveled,/_will be brought down to the earth, to the dust.

18132.text: §¶On that day, this song will be sung in the land of Judah:/Ours is a strong city!/_God makes salvation its walls and ramparts.

18133.text: /Open the gates and let a righteous nation enter,/_a nation that keeps faith.

18134.text: /Those with sound thoughts you will keep in peace,/_in peace because they trust in you.

18135.text: /Trust in the Lord forever,/_for the Lord is a rock for all ages.

18136.text: /He has thrown down those living on high,/_and he will level the lofty town,/_leveling it down to the earth;/_he will bring it down to dust.

18137.text: /The feet trample it,/_the feet of the poor,/_the steps of the needy.

18138.text: ¶The way of the righteous is level;/_you clear a path for the righteous.

18139.text: /In the path of your justice, Lord, we wait for you;/with all our being, we long for your name and your acclaim.

18140.text: /_At night I long for you with my whole being;/_my spirit within me watches for you./When your judgments are at work in the earth,/_those living in the world learn righteousness.

18141.text: /When the wicked are favored, they don’t learn righteousness;/_even among those who do right they do wrong,/_and they fail to see the Lord’s majesty.

18142.text: /Lord, your hand is lifted up,/_but they don’t see./_Let them see and shrink back because of your zeal for your people;/_your burning anger that consumes your enemies.

18143.text: ¶Lord, grant us peace,/_because all that we have done has been your doing.

18144.text: /Lord our God, other masters besides you have ruled us,/_but we will profess your name alone.

18145.text: /The dead don’t live; ghosts don’t rise./_Indeed, you have punished and destroyed them,/_and abolished all memory of them.

18146.text: /You’ve enlarged the nation, Lord./_You’ve enlarged the nation; you are glorified./_You’ve expanded all the land’s boundaries.

18147.text: /Lord, in distress they sought you out;/_they poured out prayers to you when you disciplined them.

18148.text: /As a pregnant woman close to childbirth is in labor pains,/_crying out in her pangs,/_so were we because of you, Lord.

18149.text: /We were pregnant, we writhed,/but we gave birth to wind./We have achieved no victories on earth;/_the inhabitants of the earth never fall.

18150.text: ¶Your dead will live, their corpses will rise,/_and those who dwell in the dust will shout for joy./Your shadow is a shadow of light,/_but you will bring down the ghosts into the underworld.

18151.text: /Go, my people, enter your rooms and shut your doors behind you./_Take cover, for in a little while the fury will be over.

18152.text: /Look! The Lord is going out from his place/_to bring the iniquity of the ruler of the earth down upon him./The earth will uncover its blood/_and will conceal its slain no longer.

18153.text: §¶On that day, the Lord will take a great sword, harsh and mighty, and will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan the writhing serpent, and will kill the dragon that is in the sea.

18154.text: On that day:¶▼Sing about a delightful vineyard!

18155.text: /_I, the Lord, am its guardian./Every moment I water it;/_night and day I guard it from attack.

18156.text: /I’m not angry,/_but if it yields thorns and thistles for me,/_I will march to battle against it;/_I will torch it completely.

18157.text: /Or let them cling to me for refuge;/_let them make peace with me;/_let them make peace with me.

18158.text: /In coming days,/_Jacob will take root;/_Israel will blossom and sprout/_and fill the whole world with produce.

18159.text: ¶Did God strike Israel as he struck those who struck him?/_Was Israel killed as his killers were killed?

18160.text: /By frightening Jerusalem, by sending her away,/_you contended with her,/_expelling with a fierce blast/_on the day of the east wind.

18161.text: /By this Jacob’s guilt is reconciled,/_and this was how his sins were finally removed:/_he made all the altar stones like shattered chalk,/_sacred poles and incense altars that couldn’t stand.

18162.text: ¶The fortified city lies alone,/_a hut forsaken,/_abandoned like the desert./Calves graze there;/_they lie down there and feed on its boughs.

18163.text: /When its branches are dry, they are broken./_Women come and set fire to it./These people have no understanding;/_therefore, their maker won’t have compassion;/_the one who formed them won’t be gracious.

18164.text: ¶On that day, the Lord will beat grain from the channel of the Euphrates up to the Valley of Egypt. You will be collected, Israelites, one by one.

18165.text: On that day, a great trumpet will be played. Those who were lost in the land of Assyria and those who were scattered in the land of Egypt will come. They will bow to the Lord at his holy mountain in Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Oh, the majestic garland of Ephraim’s drunks/_and the fading flower of its splendid beauty/_on the head that flows with perfume/_of those hammered with wine.

18167.text: /Look! The Lord has someone who is powerful and strong;/_like a hailstorm, a disastrous tempest,/_like a downpour of mighty, overflowing waters,/_he can level them to the ground with his hand.

18168.text: /The majestic garland of Ephraim’s drunks/_will be trampled underfoot.

18169.text: /_The withered flower, which is a thing of beauty/_as it sits on the head of those bloated with fat,/_will be like an early fig before the summer harvest:/_whoever sees it swallows it as soon as it is in hand.

18170.text: ¶On that day, the Lord of heavenly forces will be a splendid garland and a beautiful wreath for the people who survive,

18171.text: and a spirit of justice for the one who sits in judgment, and a strength for those who repel the assault at the gate.

18172.text: ¶These also stagger from wine and stumble from beer:/_priest and prophet stagger from beer;/_they are confused by wine;/_they stray on account of beer;/_they err when receiving visions;/_they stumble when making judgments.

18173.text: /All the tables are covered with vomit;/_filth overruns the place.

18174.text: ¶To whom will God teach knowledge?/_To whom will he explain the message?/_To those just weaned from milk?/_To those who have hardly outgrown the breast?

18175.text: /It is “tsav letsav, tsav lestav; qav leqav, qav leqav,”/_a little of this, a little of that.

18176.text: /With derisive speech and a foreign tongue,/_he will speak to this people.

18177.text: /He has said to them,/_“This is the place of rest;/_give rest to the weary;/_this is the place of repose”;/_but they refused to listen.

18178.text: /So the Lord’s word will be for them:/_“tsav letsav, tsav letsav; qav leqav, qav leqav,”/_a little of this, a little of that./So that they will go and stagger backward,/_they will be broken, snared, and captured.

18179.text: §¶Therefore, hear the Lord’s word,/_you scoffers who rule this people in Jerusalem.

18180.text: /You said, “We’ve cut a deal with death;/_with the underworld we made a pact./When the overflowing flood passes through, it won’t reach us;/_for we have made lies our hiding place,/_and in falsehood we take shelter.”

18181.text: /Therefore, the Lord God says:/Look! I’m laying in Zion a stone,/_a tested stone, a valuable cornerstone,/_a sure foundation:/_the one who trusts won’t tremble.

18182.text: /I will make justice the measuring line/_and righteousness the plumb line./But hail will sweep away the hiding place of lies,/_and water will overflow the shelter.

18183.text: /Your deal with death will be dissolved,/_and your pact with the grave won’t stand./The rushing flood: when it passes through,/_you will be annihilated by it.

18184.text: /Every time it passes through it will take you,/_for morning by morning it will pass,/_by day and by night./_It will be nothing but terror to understand the message.

18185.text: /The bed is too short to stretch out,/_and the shroud is too narrow to cover oneself.

18186.text: ¶Just as on Mount Perazim, the Lord will rise up;/_as in the Gibeon Valley he will rage to do his deed—strange is his deed!—/_And to work his work—foreign is his work!

18187.text: /So now stop your scoffing,/_or your chains will be tightened,/_because destruction has been ordered—I have heard it!—/_by the Lord God of heavenly forces against the whole land.

18188.text: §¶Listen and hear my voice;/_pay attention and hear my word:

18189.text: /Does the plowman plow without stopping for planting,/_opening and harrowing their ground?

18190.text: /When he has smoothed its surface,/_doesn’t he scatter fennel, and sow cumin,/_and plant wheat and barley in their places,/_and spelt as a border?

18191.text: /They are properly ordered;/_their God directs them.

18192.text: /Fennel isn’t threshed with a threshing sledge,/_nor is a cart wheel rolled over cumin,/_but fennel is beaten with a staff,/_and cumin with a rod.

18193.text: /Bread grain is crushed,/_but the thresher doesn’t thresh it forever./_He drives the cart wheel over it;/_he spreads it out but doesn’t crush it.

18194.text: /This also comes from the Lord of heavenly forces,/_who gives wondrous counsel and increases wisdom.

18195.text: §¶Oh, Ariel, Ariel,/_town where David encamped!/Year by year, let the festivals come around—

18196.text: /_but I will oppress Ariel./There will be mourning and lamentation;/_she will be like an Ariel to me.

18197.text: /I will surround you like a wall,/_and I will lay a siege against you with assault towers,/_and I will raise up siegeworks against you.

18198.text: /You will be brought down;/_from the ground you will speak;/_from low in the dust your speech will come./Your voice will be like a ghost’s from the earth;/_from the dust your words will whisper.

18199.text: /But your many enemies will be like fine dust,/_the terrible horde like passing chaff./Suddenly, in an instant,

18200.text: /the Lord of heavenly forces will come to you with thunder, earthquake, and a mighty voice,/_with whirlwind, tempest, and flames of devouring fire.

18201.text: /The horde of nations fighting against Ariel,/_and all who make war on her and her fortress and besiege her,/_will be like a dream, a vision of the night.

18202.text: /It will be like when a hungry person dreams of eating/_but wakes up and the mouth is empty./_Or when a thirsty person dreams of drinking/_but wakes up and has a dry throat./So will it be for all the horde of nations/_who fight against Mount Zion.

18203.text: ¶Be shocked and stunned;/_blind yourselves; be blind!/Be drunk, but not on wine;/_stagger, but not on account of beer!

18204.text: /The Lord has poured on you a spirit of deep sleep,/_and has shut your eyes, you prophets,/_and covered your heads, you seers.

18205.text: ¶This entire vision has become for you like the words of a sealed scroll. When they give it to one who can read, saying, “Read this,” that one will say, “I can’t, because it’s sealed.”

18206.text: And when the scroll is given to one who can’t read, saying, “Read this,” that one will say, “I can’t read.”

18207.text: §¶The Lord says:/Since these people turn toward me with their mouths,/_and honor me with lip service/_while their heart is distant from me,/_and their fear of me is just a human command that has been memorized,

18208.text: /_I will go on doing amazing things to these people,/_shocking and startling things./The wisdom of their wise will perish,/_and the discernment of their discerning will be hidden.

18209.text: /Doom to those who hide their plan deep, away from the Lord,/_whose deeds are in the dark,/_who say, “Who sees us? Who knows us?”

18210.text: /You have everything backward!/_Should the potter be thought of as clay?/_Should what is made say of its maker,/_“He didn’t make me”?/_Should what is shaped say of the one who shaped it,/_“He doesn’t understand”?

18211.text: ¶In just a little while won’t Lebanon become farmland once again,/_and the farmland be considered a forest?

18212.text: /On that day: The deaf will hear the words of a scroll and, freed from dimness and darkness, the eyes of the blind will see.

18213.text: /The poor will again find joy in the Lord,/_and the neediest of people will rejoice in the holy one of Israel.

18214.text: /The tyrant will be no more,/_the mocker will perish,/_and all who plot evil will be eliminated:

18215.text: /_all who incriminate others wrongly,/_who entrap the judge in the gate,/_and pointlessly postpone justice for the innocent.

18216.text: ¶Therefore, proclaims the Lord,/_the God of the house of Jacob,/_who redeemed Abraham:/Jacob won’t be ashamed now,/_and his face won’t grow pale now.

18217.text: /When he sees his children among them,/_the work of my hands,/_proclaiming my name holy,/_they will make holy the holy one of Jacob,/_and stand in awe of Israel’s God.

18218.text: /Those who wander in spirit will have understanding,/_and those who grumble will gain insight.

18219.text: §¶Doom to you, rebellious children, says the Lord,/_who make a plan, which is not mine;/_who weave a plot, but not by my spirit,/_piling up sin on sin;

18220.text: /_setting out to go down to Egypt without consulting me,/_taking refuge in Pharaoh’s refuge and hiding in Egypt’s shadow.

18221.text: /Pharaoh’s refuge will become your shame,/_hiding in Egypt’s shadow your disgrace.

18222.text: /Though their officials are in Zoan,/_and their messengers reach Hanes,
