18223.text: /_all will become shamed because of a people who can’t assist them./They are no help; they are no profit;/_rather, shame and disgrace.

18224.text: ¶An oracle about the beasts in the arid southern plain.¶▼Through a land of distress and danger,/_lioness and roaring lion, viper and flying serpent,/_they will carry their wealth on donkeys’ shoulders/_and their treasures on camels’ humps to a people who won’t profit,

18225.text: /_for Egypt’s help is utterly worthless./Therefore, I call her Rahab Who Sits Still.

18226.text: ¶Now go, write it before them on a tablet,/_inscribe it on a scroll,/_so in the future it will endure as a witness.

18227.text: /These are rebellious people, lying children,/_children unwilling to hear the Lord’s teaching,

18228.text: /_who say to the seers, “Don’t foresee,”/_and to the visionaries, “Don’t report truthful visions;/_tell us flattering things;/_envision deceptions;

18229.text: /_get out of the way;/_step off the path;/_let’s have no more ‘holy one of Israel.’”

18230.text: ¶Therefore, the holy one of Israel says:¶▼Because you reject this word/_and trust in oppression and cunning and rely on them,

18231.text: /_your sin will be like a crack in a high wall; it bulges, about to fall:/_suddenly, in an instant, it breaks!

18232.text: /Its breaking is like the breaking of a storage jar/_that is totally shattered./No piece from among its fragments will be large enough to take fire from a hearth,/_or to dip water from a cistern.

18233.text: ¶Therefore, the Lord God,/_the holy one of Israel, says:/In return and rest you will be saved;/_quietness and trust will be your strength—/_but you refused.

18234.text: /You said,/“No! We’ll flee on horses”—/_therefore, you will indeed flee—/_“and we’ll ride off; on swift steeds we will ride”—/_therefore, your pursuers will be swift.

18235.text: /One thousand will flee at the threat of one,/_and at the threat of five you will flee,/_until you are left like a flagstaff on a mountaintop,/_like a flag on a hill.

18236.text: /Nonetheless, the Lord is waiting to be merciful to you,/_and will rise up to show you compassion./The Lord is a God of justice;/_happy are all who wait for him.

18237.text: §¶People in Zion, who live in Jerusalem, you will weep no longer. God will certainly be merciful to you. Hearing the sound of your outcry, God will answer you.

18238.text: Though the Lord gives you the bread of distress and the water of oppression, your teacher will no longer hide, but you will see your teacher.

18239.text: If you stray to the right or the left, you will hear a word that comes from behind you: “This is the way; walk in it.”

18240.text: You will defile your silver‑plated idols and your gold‑covered priestly vest, and you will scatter them like menstrual rags. “Get out,” you will say to them.

18241.text: ¶God will provide rain for the seed you sow in the ground, and the food the ground produces will be rich and abundant. On that day, your cattle will graze in large pastures.

18242.text: The oxen and donkeys that are working the ground will eat tasty feed spread for them with shovel and fork.

18243.text: ¶On every lofty mountain, and on every high hill, streams will run with water on the day of the great massacre, when the towers fall.

18244.text: The light of the moon will be like the light of the sun, and the light of the sun will be seven times brighter—like the light of seven days—on the day that the Lord bandages the people’s brokenness and heals the wounds inflicted by his blows.

18245.text: §¶Look there! The Lord is coming from far away;/_his anger blazing, his smoke‑cloud thick./His lips are full of fury;/_his tongue is like a devouring fire.

18246.text: /His breath is like a raging river that reaches up to the neck,/_to shake the nations with a sieve of destruction,/_and to put a misleading rein on the people’s jaws.

18247.text: /There will be singing for you/_as on the night that people celebrate a festival./_The heart will be joyful as it is when one goes with a flute/_to the Lord’s mountain,/_to the rock of Israel.

18248.text: /The Lord will unleash his majestic voice/_and display his crushing arm/_in furious anger, with a flame of consuming fire,/_in stormy rain and hail.

18249.text: /The Lord’s voice will terrify Assyria;/_with a rod he will smite it.

18250.text: /And every crack that is made in the foundation wall,/_which the Lord will bring down upon him,/_will be accompanied by timbrels and lyres./The Lord will raise his arm and fight against Assyria in battle.

18251.text: /His place for burning was arranged long ago;/_it is indeed made ready for a king./God has made its wood pile wide and deep,/_fire and wood in abundance./_The breath of the Lord, like a stream of brimstone, ignites it.

18252.text: §¶Doom to those going down to Egypt for help!/_They rely on horses,/_trust in chariots because they are many,/_and on riders because they are very strong./But they don’t look to the holy one of Israel;/_they don’t seek the Lord.

18253.text: /But God also knows how to bring disaster;/_he has not taken back his words./God will rise up against the house of evildoers/_and against the help of those who do wrong.

18254.text: /Egypt is human and not divine;/_their horses are flesh and not spirit./The Lord will extend his hand;/_the helper will stumble,/_those helped will fall,/_and they will all die together.

18255.text: ¶The Lord has said to me:/When the lion growls,/_the young lion, over its prey,/_though a band of shepherds is summoned against it,/_isn’t scared off by their noise/_or frightened by their roar./So the Lord of heavenly forces will go down/_to fight on Mount Zion and on her hill.

18256.text: /Like birds flying aloft,/_so the Lord of heavenly forces will shield Jerusalem:/_shielding and saving, sparing and rescuing.

18257.text: ¶People of Israel, return to the one whom you have deeply betrayed!

18258.text: On that day, you will each reject the idols of silver and the idols of gold, which you have sinfully made for yourselves.

18259.text: ¶Assyria will fall, but not by a human sword—/_a sword not made by humans will devour them./_They will flee before the sword;/_their young men will become forced laborers.

18260.text: /In horror they will flee from their stronghold;/_their officers will be terrified at the signal,/_says the Lord, whose fire is in Zion/_and whose oven is in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶See here: A king rules to promote righteousness;/_rulers govern to promote justice,

18262.text: /_each like a shelter from the wind/_and a refuge from a storm,/_like streams of water in a wasteland,/_like the shade of a massive cliff in a worn‑out land.

18263.text: /Then the eyes of those who can see will no longer be blind,/_the ears of those who can hear will listen,

18264.text: /_the minds of the rash will know and comprehend,/_and the tongues of those who stammer will speak fluently and plainly.

18265.text: /Then a fool will no longer be called honorable,/_nor a villain considered respectable.

18266.text: /Fools speak folly;/_their minds devise wickedness,/_acting irreverently,/_speaking falsely of the Lord,/_leaving the hungry empty,/_and depriving the thirsty of drink.

18267.text: /As for the villain, his villainies are evil./_He plans schemes to destroy the poor with lying words,/_even when the needy speak justly.

18268.text: /But an honorable person plans honorable things/_and stands up for what is honorable.

18269.text: §¶Women of leisure, stand up! Hear my voice!/_Carefree daughters, listen to my word!

18270.text: /In a little over a year,/_the carefree will shudder,/_because the grape harvest will fail;/_the vintage won’t arrive.

18271.text: /Tremble, all of you who are at ease;/_shudder, all of you who are secure!/Strip yourselves, bare your skin,/_and tie mourning clothes around your waist,

18272.text: /_beating your breasts for the pleasant fields,/_for the fruitful vine,

18273.text: /_for my people’s soil/_growing barbs and thorns,/_for all the joyous houses/_in the jubilant town.

18274.text: /The palace will be deserted,/_the crowded city abandoned./Stronghold and watchtower/_will become empty fields forever,/_suited for the pleasure of wild donkeys,/_and a pasture for flocks—

18275.text: /_until a spirit from on high/_is poured out on us,/_and the desert turns into farmland, and the farmland is considered a forest.

18276.text: /Then justice will reside in wild lands,/_and righteousness will abide in farmlands.

18277.text: /The fruit of righteousness will be peace,/_and the outcome of righteousness,/_calm and security forever.

18278.text: /Then my people will live in a peaceful dwelling,/_in secure homes, in carefree resting places.

18279.text: /Even if the forest falls/_and the humbled city is laid low,

18280.text: /_those who sow beside any stream will be happy,/_sending out ox and donkey to graze.

18281.text: §¶Doom to the destroyer left undestroyed,/_you traitor whom none have betrayed:/when you have finished destroying, you will be destroyed;/_and when you have stopped betraying, they will betray you.

18282.text: ¶Lord, show us favor;/_we hope in you./Be our strength every morning,/_our salvation in times of distress.

18283.text: /At the noise, peoples fled;/_on account of your roar, nations scattered.

18284.text: /They gathered spoil like insects;/_they rushed upon it like a swarm of locusts.

18285.text: /The Lord is exalted; he lives on high,/_filling Zion with justice and righteousness.

18286.text: /He will provide security during a lifetime:/_a source of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge—/_fear of the Lord will be Zion’s treasure.

18287.text: ¶But then those in Ariel cried out in the streets;/_messengers of peace wept bitterly.

18288.text: /The highways were deserted;/_travelers left the road./The covenant was broken;/_solemn pledges were rejected;/_no one cared for humanity.

18289.text: /The land mourned; it wasted away;/_Lebanon was ashamed; it withered./Sharon became like the desert,/_and Bashan and Carmel were dropping their leaves.

18290.text: ¶Now I will arise, says the Lord./_Now I will exalt myself; now I will stand tall.

18291.text: /You conceive straw, give birth to stubble;/_your breath is a fire that devours you.

18292.text: /Peoples will be burned to lime,/_thorns cut up and set ablaze.

18293.text: /You who are far away, hear what I have done;/_and you who are near, know my strength!

18294.text: ¶Sinners became terrified in Zion;/_trembling seized the godless:/_“Who among us can live with the devouring fire?/_Who among us can live with the everlasting blaze?”

18295.text: /The one who walks righteously and speaks truthfully,/_who rejects profit from extortion,/_who waves away a bribe instead of grabbing it,/_who won’t listen to bloody plots,/_and who won’t contemplate doing something evil.

18296.text: /He will live on the heights;/_fortresses in the cliffs will be his refuge./His food will be provided,/_his water guaranteed.

18297.text: /When you gaze upon a king in his glamour/_and look at the surrounding land,

18298.text: /_in dismay you will think:/_Where is the one who counts?/_Where is the one who weighs?/_Where is the one who counts towers?

18299.text: /You will no longer see the defiant people,/_the people of speech too obscure to understand,/_who stammer in an incomprehensible language.

18300.text: /Gaze upon Zion, our festival town./_Your eyes will see Jerusalem,/_a carefree dwelling,/_a tent that is not packed up,/_whose stakes are never pulled up,/_whose ropes won’t snap.

18301.text: /The Lord’s majesty will be there for us:/_as a place of rivers, broad streams/_where no boat will go,/_no majestic ship will cross.

18302.text: /The Lord is our judge;/_the Lord is our leader;/_the Lord is our king—/_he will deliver us.

18303.text: /Your ropes are loosened;/_they can’t hold the mast firmly;/_they can’t spread the sail./Then abundant spoil will be divided;/_even the lame will seize spoil.

18304.text: /And no inhabitant will say, “I’m sick.”/_The people living there will be forgiven their sin.

18305.text: §¶Draw near, you nations, to hear;/_and listen, you peoples./Hear, earth and all who fill it,/_world and all its offspring.

18306.text: /The Lord rages against all the nations,/_and is angry with all their armies./God is about to wipe them out/_and has prepared them for slaughter.

18307.text: /Their dead will be cast out,/_the stench of their corpses will rise,/_and the mountains will melt from their blood.

18308.text: /All the stars of heaven will dissolve,/_the skies will roll up like a scroll,/_and all the stars will fall,/_like a leaf withering from a vine,/_like fruit from a fig tree.

18309.text: ¶When my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens,/_it will descend upon Edom for judgment,/_upon a people I have doomed for destruction.

18310.text: /The Lord has a sword covered with blood;/_it is soaked with fat/_from the blood of lambs and goats,/_from the kidney fat of rams,/_for the Lord has a sacrifice in Bozrah,/_a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

18311.text: /Wild oxen will fall with them,/_steers with mighty bulls,/_and their land will be drenched with blood;/_its soil soaked with fat.

18312.text: /The Lord has a day of vengeance,/_a year of payback for Zion’s cause.

18313.text: ¶Edom’s streams will be turned into pitch,/_its dust into sulfur,/_and its land will become burning pitch.

18314.text: /Night and day won’t be extinguished;/_its smoke will go up forever./From generation to generation it will lie waste;/_no one will ever pass through it again.

18315.text: /Screech owls and crows will possess it;/_owls and ravens will live there./God will stretch over it the measuring line of chaos/_and the plummet stone of emptiness over its officials.

18316.text: /No Kingdom There, they will call it,/_and all its princes will disappear.

18317.text: /Thorns will grow up in its palaces,/_weeds and brambles in its fortresses./It will be a dwelling for jackals,/_a home for ostriches.

18318.text: /Wildcats will meet hyenas,/_the goat demon will call to his friends,/_and there Lilith will lurk/_and find her resting place.

18319.text: /There the snake will nest and lay eggs/_and brood and hatch in its shadow./There too vultures will gather,/_each with its mate.

18320.text: /Consult the Lord’s scroll and read:/_Not one of these will be missing;/_none will lack its mate./_God’s own mouth has commanded;/_God’s own spirit has gathered them.

18321.text: /God has cast the lot for them;/_God’s hand allotted it to them with the measuring line./They will possess it forever;/_they will live in it from generation to generation.

18322.text: §¶The desert and the dry land will be glad;/_the wilderness will rejoice and blossom like the crocus.

18323.text: /They will burst into bloom,/_and rejoice with joy and singing./They will receive the glory of Lebanon,/_the splendor of Carmel and Sharon./They will see the Lord’s glory,/_the splendor of our God.

18324.text: ¶Strengthen the weak hands,/_and support the unsteady knees.

18325.text: /Say to those who are panicking:/_“Be strong! Don’t fear!/_Here’s your God,/_coming with vengeance;/_with divine retribution/_God will come to save you.”

18326.text: ¶Then the eyes of the blind will be opened,/_and the ears of the deaf will be cleared.

18327.text: /Then the lame will leap like the deer,/_and the tongue of the speechless will sing./Waters will spring up in the desert,/_and streams in the wilderness.

18328.text: /The burning sand will become a pool,/_and the thirsty ground, fountains of water./The jackals’ habitat, a pasture;/_grass will become reeds and rushes.

18329.text: /A highway will be there./_It will be called The Holy Way./The unclean won’t travel on it,/_but it will be for those walking on that way./Even fools won’t get lost on it;

18330.text: /_no lion will be there,/_and no predator will go up on it./None of these will be there;/_only the redeemed will walk on it.

18331.text: /The Lord’s ransomed ones will return and enter Zion with singing,/_with everlasting joy upon their heads./Happiness and joy will overwhelm them;/_grief and groaning will flee away.

18332.text: §¶Assyria’s King Sennacherib marched against all of Judah’s fortified cities and captured them in the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah.

18333.text: Assyria’s king sent his field commander from Lachish, together with a large army, to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. He stood at the water channel of the Upper Pool, which is on the road to the field where clothes are washed.

18334.text: Hilkiah’s son Eliakim, who was the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and Asaph’s son Joah the recorder went out to them.

18335.text: ¶Then the field commander said to them, “Say to Hezekiah: Assyria’s Great King says this: Why do you feel so confident?

18336.text: Do you think that empty words are the same as good strategy and the strength to fight? Who are you trusting that you now rebel against me?

18337.text: It appears that you are trusting in a staff—Egypt—that’s nothing but a broken reed! It will stab the hand of anyone who leans on it! That’s all that Pharaoh, Egypt’s king, is to anyone who trusts in him.

18338.text: Now suppose you say to me, ‘We trust in the Lord our God.’ Isn’t he the one whose shrines and altars Hezekiah removed, telling Judah and Jerusalem, ‘You must worship only at this altar’?

18339.text: ¶“So now, make a wager with my master, Assyria’s king. I’ll give you two thousand horses if you can supply the riders!

18340.text: How will you drive back even the least important official among my master’s servants when you are relying on Egypt for chariots and riders?

18341.text: What’s more, do you think I’ve marched against this place to destroy it without the Lord’s support? It was the Lord who told me, ‘March against this land and destroy it!’”

18342.text: ¶Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the field commander, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, because we understand it. Don’t speak with us in Hebrew, because the people on the wall will hear it.”

18343.text: ¶The field commander said to them, “Did my master send me to speak these words just to you and your master and not also to the men on the wall? They are the ones who will have to eat their dung and drink their urine along with you.”

18344.text: Then the field commander stood up and shouted in Hebrew at the top of his voice: “Listen to the message of the great king, Assyria’s king.

18345.text: The king says this: Don’t let Hezekiah lie to you. He won’t be able to rescue you.

18346.text: Don’t let Hezekiah persuade you to trust the Lord by saying, ‘The Lord will certainly rescue us. This city won’t be handed over to Assyria’s king.’

18347.text: ¶“Don’t listen to Hezekiah, because this is what Assyria’s king says: Surrender to me and come out. Then each of you will eat from your own vine and fig tree and drink water from your own well

18348.text: until I come to take you to a land just like your land. It will be a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18349.text: Don’t let Hezekiah fool you by saying, ‘The Lord will rescue us.’ Did any of the other gods of the nations save their lands from the power of Assyria’s king?

18350.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Did they rescue Samaria from my power?

18351.text: Which one of the gods from those countries has rescued their land from my power? Will the Lord save Jerusalem from my power?”

18352.text: ¶But they kept quiet and didn’t answer him with a single word, because King Hezekiah’s command was, “Don’t answer him!”

18353.text: Hilkiah’s son Eliakim, who was the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and Asaph’s son Joah the recorder came to Hezekiah with ripped clothes. They told him what the field commander had said.

18354.text: §¶When King Hezekiah heard this, he ripped his clothes, covered himself with mourning clothes, and went to the Lord’s temple.

18355.text: He sent Eliakim the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests to the prophet Isaiah, Amoz’s son. They were all wearing mourning clothes.

18356.text: They said to him, “Hezekiah says this: Today is a day of distress, punishment, and humiliation. It’s as if children are ready to be born, but there’s no strength to see it through.

18357.text: Perhaps the Lord your God heard all the words of the field commander who was sent by his master, Assyria’s king. He insulted the living God! Perhaps he will punish him for the words that the Lord your God has heard. Offer up a prayer for those few people who still survive.”

18358.text: ¶When King Hezekiah’s servants got to Isaiah,

18359.text: Isaiah said to them, “Say this to your master: The Lord says this: Don’t be afraid at the words you heard, which the officers of Assyria’s king have used to insult me.

18360.text: I’m about to mislead him, so when he hears a rumor, he’ll go back to his own country. Then I’ll have him cut down by the sword in his own land.”

18361.text: ¶The field commander heard that the Assyrian king had left Lachish. So he went back to the king and found him attacking Libnah.

18362.text: Then the Assyrian king learned that Cush’s King Tirhakah was on his way to fight against him. So he sent messengers to Hezekiah again:

18363.text: “Say this to Judah’s King Hezekiah: Don’t let the God you trust deceive you by saying, ‘Jerusalem won’t fall to the Assyrian king.’

18364.text: You yourself have heard what Assyrian kings do to other countries, wiping them out. Is it likely that you will be saved?

18365.text: Did the gods of the nations that my ancestors destroyed save them, the gods of Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, or the people of Eden in Telassar?

18366.text: Where now is Hamath’s king, Arpad’s king, or the kings of Lair, Sepharvaim, Hena, or Ivvah?”

18367.text: §¶Hezekiah took the letters from the messengers and read them. Then he went to the temple and spread them out before the Lord.

18369.text: ¶“Lord of heavenly forces, God of Israel: you sit enthroned on the winged creatures. You alone are God over all the earth’s kingdoms. You made both heaven and earth.

18370.text: Lord, turn your ear this way and hear! Lord, open your eyes and see! Listen to Sennacherib’s words. He sent them to insult the living God!

18371.text: It’s true, Lord, that the Assyrian kings have destroyed all the nations and their lands.

18372.text: The Assyrians burned the gods of those nations with fire because they aren’t real gods. They are only man‑made creations of wood and stone. That’s how the Assyrians could destroy them.

18373.text: So now, Lord our God, please save us from Sennacherib’s power! Then all the earth’s kingdoms will know that you alone are Lord.”

18374.text: ¶Then Isaiah, Amoz’s son, sent a message to Hezekiah: The Lord God of Israel says this: Since you prayed to me about Assyria’s King Sennacherib,

18375.text: this is the message that the Lord has spoken against him:¶▼The young woman, Daughter Zion, despises you and mocks you;/_Daughter Jerusalem shakes her head behind your back.

18376.text: /Whom did you insult and ridicule?/_Against whom did you raise your voice/_and look on with disdain?/_It was against the holy one of Israel!

18377.text: /With your servants, you’ve insulted the Lord;/_you said, “I, with my many chariots,/_have gone up to the highest mountains,/_to the farthest reaches of Lebanon./I have cut down its tallest cedars,/_the best of its pine trees./I have reached its most remote lodging place,/_its best forest.

18378.text: /I have dug wells,/_have drunk water in foreign lands./With my own feet, I dried up all of Egypt’s streams.”

18379.text: /Haven’t you heard?/I set this up long ago;/_I planned it in the distant past!/Now I have made it happen,/_making fortified cities collapse into piles of rubble.

18380.text: /Their citizens have lost their power;/_they are frightened and dismayed./They’ve become like plants in a field,/_tender green shoots,/_the grass on rooftops,/_blasted by the east wind.

18381.text: /I know where you are,/_how you go out and come in,/_and how you rage against me.

18382.text: /Because you rage against me and because your pride has reached my ears,/_I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth./_I will make you go back the same way you came.

18383.text: ¶Now this will be the sign for you, Hezekiah: This year you will eat what grows by itself. Next year you will eat what grows from that. But in the third year, plant seed and harvest it; plant vineyards and eat their fruit.

18384.text: The survivors of Judah’s family who have escaped will put down roots and bear fruit above.

18385.text: Those who remain will go out from Jerusalem, and those who survive will go out from Mount Zion. The zeal of the Lord of heavenly forces will do this.

18386.text: ¶Therefore, the Lord says this about Assyria’s king: He won’t enter this city. He won’t shoot a single arrow here. He won’t come near the city with a shield. He won’t build a ramp to besiege it.

18387.text: He’ll go back by the same way he came. He won’t enter this city, declares the Lord.

18388.text: I will defend this city and save it for my sake and for the sake of my servant David.

18389.text: ¶The Lord’s messenger went out and struck down one hundred eighty‑five thousand soldiers in the Assyrian camp. When people got up the next morning, there were dead bodies everywhere.

18390.text: So Assyria’s King Sennacherib left and went back to Nineveh, where he stayed.

18391.text: Later, while he was worshipping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with a sword. Then they escaped to the land of Ararat. His son Esarhaddon ruled after him.

18392.text: §¶At about that time Hezekiah became deathly sick. The prophet Isaiah, Amoz’s son, came to him and said: “The Lord God says this: Put your affairs in order because you are about to die. You won’t survive this.”

18393.text: ¶Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord:

18394.text: “Please, Lord, remember how I’ve walked before you in truth and sincerity. I’ve done what you consider to be good.” Then Hezekiah cried and cried.

18395.text: ¶Then the Lord’s word came to Isaiah:

18396.text: “Go and say to Hezekiah: The Lord, the God of your ancestor David, says this: I have heard your prayer and have seen your tears. I will add fifteen years to your life.

18397.text: I will rescue you and this city from the power of the Assyrian king. I will defend this city.

18398.text: This will be your sign from the Lord that he will do what he promised:

18399.text: once the shadow cast by the sun descends on the steps of Ahaz, I will make it back up ten steps.” And the sun went back ten of the steps that it had already descended.

18400.text: ¶A composition by Judah’s King Hezekiah when he was sick and then recovered from his sickness:

18401.text: ¶I thought, I must depart in the prime of my life;/_I have been relegated to the gates of the underworld for the rest of my life.

18402.text: /I thought, I won’t see the Lord./_The Lord is in the land of the living./I won’t look upon humans again/_or be with the inhabitants of the world.

18403.text: /My lifetime is plucked up/_and taken from me like a shepherd’s tent./My life is shriveled like woven cloth;/_God cuts me off from the loom./Between daybreak and nightfall/_you carry out your verdict against me.

18404.text: /I cried out until morning:/_“Like a lion God crushes all my bones./Between daybreak and nightfall/_you carry out your verdict against me.

18405.text: /Like a swallow I chirp;/_I moan like a dove./My eyes have grown weary looking to heaven./_Lord, I’m overwhelmed; support me!”

18406.text: ¶What can I say?/_God has spoken to me;/_he himself has acted./I will wander my whole life/_with a bitter spirit.

18407.text: /The Lord Most High is the one who gives life to every heart,/_who gives life to the spirit!

18408.text: /Look, he indeed exchanged my bitterness for wholeness.¶You yourself have spared my whole being/_from the pit of destruction,/_because you have cast all my sins/_behind your back.

18409.text: /The underworld can’t thank you,/_nor can death praise you;/_those who go down to the pit/_can’t hope for your faithfulness.

18410.text: /The living, the living can thank you, as I do today./_Parents will tell children about your faithfulness.

18411.text: /The Lord has truly saved me,/_and we will make music at the Lord’s house all the days of our lives.

18412.text: ¶Then Isaiah said, “Prepare a salve made from figs, put it on the swelling, and he’ll get better.”

18413.text: ¶Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “What’s the sign that I’ll be able to go up to the Lord’s temple?”

18414.text: §¶At that time, Babylon’s King Merodach‑baladan, Baladan’s son, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, for he heard that he had been ill and had recovered.

18415.text: Hezekiah was pleased, and he showed them his treasury—the silver and the gold, the spices and fine oil—and everything in his armory, all that was found in his storerooms. There wasn’t a thing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah didn’t show them.

18416.text: ¶Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and said to him, “What did these men say? Where did they come from?”¶Hezekiah replied, “They came to me from a distant land, from Babylon.”

18417.text: ¶So Isaiah said, “What did they see in your house?”¶Hezekiah said, “They saw everything in my house. There was nothing in my storerooms that I didn’t show them.”

18418.text: ¶Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord of heavenly forces:

18419.text: Days are coming when all that is in your house, which your ancestors have stored up until this day, will be carried to Babylon. Nothing will be left, says the Lord.

18420.text: Some of your sons, your own descendants whom you fathered, will be taken to become eunuchs in the king of Babylon’s palace.”

18421.text: ¶Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The Lord’s word that you delivered is good,” since he thought, That means there will be peace and security in my lifetime.

18423.text: /Speak compassionately to Jerusalem,/_and proclaim to her that her compulsory service has ended,/_that her penalty has been paid,/_that she has received from the Lord’s hand double for all her sins!

18424.text: ¶A voice is crying out:/“Clear the Lord’s way in the desert!/_Make a level highway in the wilderness for our God!

18425.text: /Every valley will be raised up,/_and every mountain and hill will be flattened./_Uneven ground will become level,/_and rough terrain a valley plain.

18426.text: /The Lord’s glory will appear,/_and all humanity will see it together;/_the Lord’s mouth has commanded it.”

18427.text: ¶A voice was saying:/_“Call out!”/And another said,/_“What should I call out?”/All flesh is grass;/_all its loyalty is like the flowers of the field.

18428.text: /The grass dries up/_and the flower withers/_when the Lord’s breath blows on it./_Surely the people are grass.

18429.text: /The grass dries up;/_the flower withers,/_but our God’s word will exist forever.

18430.text: ¶Go up on a high mountain,/_messenger Zion!/Raise your voice and shout,/_messenger Jerusalem!/Raise it; don’t be afraid;/_say to the cities of Judah,/_“Here is your God!”

18431.text: /Here is the Lord God,/_coming with strength,/_with a triumphant arm,/_bringing his reward with him/_and his payment before him.

18432.text: /Like a shepherd, God will tend the flock;/_he will gather lambs in his arms/_and lift them onto his lap./_He will gently guide the nursing ewes.

18433.text: §¶Who has measured the waters in the palm of a hand/_or gauged the heavens with a ruler/_or scooped the earth’s dust up in a measuring cup/_or weighed the mountains on a scale/_and the hills in a balance?

18434.text: /Who directed the Lord’s spirit/_and acted as God’s advisor?

18435.text: /Whom did he consult for enlightenment?/_Who taught him the path of justice and knowledge/_and explained to him the way of understanding?

18436.text: /Look, the nations are like a drop in a bucket,/_and valued as dust on a scale./_Look, God weighs the islands like fine dust.

18437.text: /Lebanon doesn’t have enough fuel;/_its animals aren’t enough for an entirely burned offering.

18438.text: /All the nations are like nothing before God./_They are viewed as less than nothing and emptiness.

18439.text: ¶So to whom will you equate God;/_to what likeness will you compare him?

18440.text: /An idol? A craftsman pours it,/_a metalworker covers it with gold,/_and fashions silver chains.

18441.text: /The one who sets up an image chooses wood that won’t rot/_and then seeks a skilled artisan/_to set up an idol that won’t move.

18442.text: /Don’t you know? Haven’t you heard?/_Wasn’t it announced to you from the beginning?/_Haven’t you understood since the earth was founded?

18443.text: /God inhabits the earth’s horizon—/_its inhabitants are like locusts—/_stretches out the skies like a curtain/_and spreads it out like a tent for dwelling.

18444.text: /_God makes dignitaries useless/_and the earth’s judges into nothing.

18445.text: /Scarcely are they planted, scarcely sown,/_scarcely is their shoot rooted in the earth/_when God breathes on them, and they dry up;/_the windstorm carries them off like straw.

18446.text: /So to whom will you compare me,/_and who is my equal? says the holy one.

18447.text: §¶Look up at the sky and consider:/_Who created these?/_The one who brings out their attendants one by one,/_summoning each of them by name./Because of God’s great strength/_and mighty power, not one is missing.

18448.text: /Why do you say, Jacob,/_and declare, Israel,/_“My way is hidden from the Lord/_my God ignores my predicament”?

18449.text: /Don’t you know? Haven’t you heard?/_The Lord is the everlasting God,/_the creator of the ends of the earth./_He doesn’t grow tired or weary./His understanding is beyond human reach,

18450.text: /_giving power to the tired/_and reviving the exhausted.

18451.text: /Youths will become tired and weary,/_young men will certainly stumble;

18452.text: /_but those who hope in the Lord/_will renew their strength;/_they will fly up on wings like eagles;/_they will run and not be tired;/_they will walk and not be weary.

18453.text: §¶Be quiet before me, coastlands./_Let the nations renew their strength./_Let them approach and speak./_Let’s draw near for a judgment.

18454.text: /Who has awakened one from the east/_and has authority to summon him to serve—/_giving him nations,/_conquering kings,/_making them like dust with his sword,/_like scattered straw with his bow?

18455.text: /He pursues them and passes untouched,/_needing no path for his feet.

18456.text: /Who has acted and who has done this,/_calling upon generation after generation since the beginning?/_I, the Lord, was first,/_and I will be the last!

18457.text: ¶The coastlands see and fear;/_the ends of the earth tremble;/_they draw near and arrive.

18458.text: /Each helps the other,/_each saying to the other, “Take courage!”

18459.text: /The craftsman encourages the metalworker;/_the one who smoothes with the hammer/_encourages the one who strikes the anvil,/_saying of the welding, “That’s good,”/_and strengthening it with nails so it won’t move.

18460.text: §¶But you, Israel my servant,/_Jacob, whom I have chosen,/_offspring of Abraham, whom I love,

18461.text: /_you whom I took from the ends of the earth/_and called from its farthest corners,/_saying to you, “You are my servant;/_I chose you and didn’t reject you”:

18462.text: /_Don’t fear, because I am with you;/_don’t be afraid, for I am your God./_I will strengthen you,/_I will surely help you;/_I will hold you/_with my righteous strong hand.

18463.text: /All who rage against you will be shamed and disgraced./_Those who contend with you/_will be as nothing and will perish.

18464.text: /You will look for your opponents,/_and won’t find them./_Those who fight you will be of no account and will die.

18465.text: /I am the Lord your God,/_who grasps your strong hand,/_who says to you,/_Don’t fear; I will help you.

18466.text: /Don’t fear, worm of Jacob,/_people of Israel!/I will help you, says the Lord./_The holy one of Israel is your redeemer.

18467.text: /Look, I’ve made you/_into a new threshing tool with sharp teeth./You will thresh mountains and pulverize them;/_you will reduce hills to straw.

18468.text: /When you winnow them,/_the wind will carry them off;/_the tempest will scatter them./You will rejoice in the Lord/_and take pride in the holy one of Israel.

18469.text: ¶The poor and the needy seek water, and there is none;/_their tongues are parched with thirst./I, the Lord, will respond to them;/_I, the God of Israel, won’t abandon them.

18470.text: /I will open streams on treeless hilltops/_and springs in valleys./I will make the desert into ponds/_and dry land into cascades of water.

18471.text: /I will plant in the desert cedar, acacia, myrtle, and olive trees;/_I will put in the wilderness cypress, elm, and pine as well,

18472.text: /_so that they will see and know/_and observe and comprehend/_that the Lord’s hand has done this,/_and the holy one of Israel has created it.

18473.text: §¶Present your case, says the Lord./_Bring forward your evidence, says Jacob’s king.

18474.text: /Let the idols approach/_and tell us what will happen./The prior things—what are they?/_Announce them, and we’ll think about them/_and know their significance./_Or proclaim to us what is to come!

18475.text: /Report things that will happen in the future,/_then we’ll know that you are gods./Do good! Or do bad!/_Then we will all be afraid and fearful.

18476.text: /Look! You are nobody, and your deeds are nothing./_Whoever chooses you is disgusting.

18477.text: /I woke up one from the north and he came;/_from the east, one who calls my name./He tramples governors like mud,/_as a potter treads clay.

18478.text: /Who announced this from the start/_so that we would know;/_from an earlier time/_so we would say, “That’s right”?/Truly, no one announced it,/_no one proclaimed it,/_and no one heard your words.

18479.text: /I first said it to Zion, “Look, here they are”;/_to Jerusalem I now send a herald.

18480.text: /But I look, and there’s no one/_among them, no counselor;/_and when I ask,/_no one can answer.

18481.text: /Look, all of them are frauds;/_their deeds amount to nothing;/_their images are a total delusion.

18482.text: §¶But here is my servant, the one I uphold;/_my chosen, who brings me delight./I’ve put my spirit upon him;/_he will bring justice to the nations.

18483.text: /He won’t cry out or shout aloud/_or make his voice heard in public.

18484.text: /He won’t break a bruised reed;/_he won’t extinguish a faint wick,/_but he will surely bring justice.

18485.text: /He won’t be extinguished or broken/_until he has established justice in the land./The coastlands await his teaching.

18486.text: ¶God the Lord says—/_the one who created the heavens,/_the one who stretched them out,/_the one who spread out the earth and its offspring,/_the one who gave breath to its people/_and life to those who walk on it—

18487.text: /I, the Lord, have called you for a good reason./_I will grasp your hand and guard you,/_and give you as a covenant to the people,/_as a light to the nations,

18488.text: /_to open blind eyes, to lead the prisoners from prison,/_and those who sit in darkness from the dungeon.

18489.text: /I am the Lord;/_that is my name;/_I don’t hand out my glory to others/_or my praise to idols.

18490.text: /The things announced in the past—look—they’ve already happened,/_but I’m declaring new things./_Before they even appear,/_I tell you about them.

18491.text: §¶Sing to the Lord a new song!/_Sing his praise from the ends of the earth!/You who sail the sea and all that fills it,/_the coastlands and their residents.

18492.text: /Let the desert and its towns shout aloud,/_the villages that Kedar inhabits./Let the cliff dwellers sing;/_from the top of the mountains let them shout.

18493.text: /Let them give the Lord glory/_and declare God’s praise in the coastlands.

18494.text: /The Lord will go out like a soldier;/_like a warrior God will stir up rage./God will shout, will roar;/_over enemies he will prevail.

18495.text: /I’ve kept still for a very long time./_I’ve been silent and restrained myself./Like a woman in labor I will moan;/_I will pant, I will gasp.

18496.text: /I will wither mountains and valleys,/_and I will dry up all their vegetation./I will turn rivers into deserts,/_and I will dry up pools.

18497.text: /I will make the blind walk a road they don’t know,/_and I will guide them in paths they don’t know./But I will make darkness before them into light/_and rough places into level ground./These things I will do;/_I won’t abandon them.

18498.text: §¶Turned backward, utterly shamed/_are those who trust in idols,/_who say to a cast image,/_“You are our god!”

18499.text: /Hear, deaf ones,/_and blind ones, look and see!

18500.text: /Who is blind if not my servant/_and deaf like my messenger whom I send?/Who is blind like the restored one,/_blind like the servant of the Lord?

18501.text: /You have seen many things, but don’t keep watch./_With ears open, you don’t hear.

18502.text: /The Lord desired for the sake of his righteousness/_to expand and glorify the Instruction.

18503.text: /But this is a people plundered and looted,/_everyone trapped in holes and hidden in dungeons./They have become plunder with no one to rescue,/_loot with no one to say, “Give it back.”

18504.text: ¶Which of you will listen to this,/_will pay attention and respond from now on?

18505.text: /Who gave Jacob to the looter,/_and Israel to the plunderers?/Wasn’t it the Lord,/_the one we sinned against?/They were not willing to walk in God’s ways,/_and wouldn’t listen to his teaching.

18506.text: /So God poured out on Jacob the heat of his anger/_and the fury of battle./It scorched him, and he didn’t know it;/_it burned him, but he didn’t give it much thought.

18507.text: §¶But now, says the Lord—/the one who created you, Jacob,/_the one who formed you, Israel:/Don’t fear, for I have redeemed you;/_I have called you by name; you are mine.

18508.text: /When you pass through the waters, I will be with you;/_when through the rivers, they won’t sweep over you./When you walk through the fire, you won’t be scorched/_and flame won’t burn you.

18509.text: /I am the Lord your God,/_the holy one of Israel, your savior./I have given Egypt as your ransom,/_Cush and Seba in your place.

18510.text: /Because you are precious in my eyes,/_you are honored, and I love you./_I give people in your place,/_and nations in exchange for your life.

18511.text: /Don’t fear,/_I am with you./From the east I’ll bring your children;/_from the west I’ll gather you.

18512.text: /I’ll say to the north, “Give them back!”/_and to the south, “Don’t detain them.”/Bring my sons from far away,/_and my daughters from the end of the earth,

18513.text: /_everyone who is called by my name/_and whom I created for my glory,/_whom I have formed and made.

18514.text: ¶Bring out the blind people who have eyes,/_the deaf ones who have ears.

18515.text: /All the nations are gathered together;/_the peoples are assembled./Which of them announced this?/_Who predicted to us the past events?/Let them bring their witnesses as a defense;/_let them hear and say, “It’s true!”

18516.text: /You are my witnesses, says the Lord,/_my servant, whom I chose,/_so that you would know and believe me/_and understand that I am the one./Before me no god was formed;/_after me there has been no other.

18517.text: /I, I am the Lord,/_and there is no savior besides me.

18518.text: /I announced, I saved, I proclaimed,/not some stranger among you./You are my witnesses, says the Lord,/_and I am God.

18519.text: /From the dawn of time, I am the one./_No one can escape my power./_I act, and who can undo it?

18520.text: §¶The Lord your redeemer,/_the holy one of Israel, says,/For your sake, I have sent an army to Babylon,/_and brought down all the bars,/_turning the Chaldeans’ singing into a lament.

18521.text: /I am the Lord, your holy one,/_Israel’s creator, your king!

18522.text: /The Lord says—who makes a way in the sea/_and a path in the mighty waters,

18523.text: /_who brings out chariot and horse,/_army and battalion;/_they will lie down together and will not rise;/_they will be extinguished, extinguished like a wick.

18524.text: /Don’t remember the prior things;/_don’t ponder ancient history.

18525.text: /Look! I’m doing a new thing;/_now it sprouts up; don’t you recognize it?/I’m making a way in the desert,/_paths in the wilderness.

18526.text: /The beasts of the field,/_the jackals and ostriches, will honor me,/_because I have put water in the desert/_and streams in the wilderness/_to give water to my people,/_my chosen ones,

18527.text: /_this people whom I formed for myself,/_who will recount my praise.

18528.text: ¶But you didn’t call out to me, Jacob;/_you were tired of me, Israel.

18529.text: /You didn’t bring me lambs for your entirely burned offering;/_you didn’t honor me with your sacrifices./I didn’t make you worship with offerings;/_I didn’t weary you with frankincense.

18530.text: /You didn’t buy spices for me with your money,/_or satisfy me with the fat of your sacrifices./Instead, you have burdened me with your sins/_and wearied me with your evil actions.

18531.text: /I, I am the one who wipes out your rebellious behavior for my sake. I won’t remember your sin.

18532.text: /Summon me, and let’s go to trial together;/_you tell your story so that you may be vindicated!

18533.text: /Your first ancestor sinned,/_and your officials rebelled against me.

18534.text: /So I made the holy officials impure,/_handed over Jacob to destruction and Israel to abuse.

18535.text: §¶But now hear this, Jacob my servant,/_and Israel, whom I have chosen.

18536.text: /The Lord your maker,/_who formed you in the womb and will help you, says:/_Don’t fear, my servant Jacob,/_Jeshurun, whom I have chosen.

18537.text: /I will pour out water upon thirsty ground/_and streams upon dry land./I will pour out my spirit upon your descendants/_and my blessing upon your offspring.

18538.text: /They will spring up from among the reeds/_like willows by flowing streams.

18539.text: /This one will say, “I am the Lord’s,”/_and that one will be named after Jacob./_Another will write on his hand, “The Lord’s”/_and will take the name Israel.

18540.text: ¶The Lord, Israel’s king and redeemer,/_the Lord of heavenly forces, says:/I am the first, and I am the last,/_and besides me there are no gods.

18541.text: /Who is like me?/_Let them speak up, explain it, and lay it out for me./Who announced long ago what is to be?/_Let them tell us what is to come.

18542.text: /Don’t tremble; have no fear!/_Didn’t I proclaim it?/_Didn’t I inform you long ago?/You are my witnesses!/_Is there a God besides me?/_There is no other rock; I know of none.

18543.text: §¶Idol‑makers are all as nothing;/_their playthings do no good./Their promoters neither see nor know anything,/_so they ought to be ashamed.

18544.text: /Who would form a god or cast an idol/_that does no good?

18545.text: /All its worshippers will be ashamed,/_and its artisans, who are only human./They will all gather and stand,/_tremble and be ashamed together.

18546.text: /A blacksmith with his tools/_works it over coals,/_and shapes it with hammers,/_and works it with his strong arm./He even becomes hungry and weak./_If he didn’t drink water, he’d pass out.

18547.text: /A carpenter stretches out a string,/_marks it out with a stylus,/_fashions it with carving tools,/_and marks it with a compass./He makes it into a human form,/_like a splendid human,/_to live in a temple.

18548.text: /He cuts down cedars for himself,/_or chooses a cypress or oak,/_selecting from all the trees of the forest./_He plants a pine, and the rain makes it grow.

18549.text: /_It becomes suitable to burn for humans,/_so he takes some of the wood and warms himself./_He kindles fire and bakes bread./He fashions a god and worships it;/_he makes an idol and bows down to it.

18550.text: /Half of it he burns in the fire;/_on that half he roasts and eats meat, and he is satisfied./He warms himself and says,/_“Ah, I’m warm, watching the fire!”

18551.text: /And the rest of it he makes into a god,/_into his idol,/_and he bows down, worships, and prays to it, saying, “Save me, for you are my god!”

18552.text: /They don’t know or comprehend,/_for their eyes can’t see/_and their minds can’t comprehend.

18553.text: /He doesn’t think,/_and has no knowledge or understanding to think:/Half of it I burned in the fire,/_and I baked bread on its coals,/_and roasted meat and ate./Should I make the rest into something detestable?/_Should I bow down to a block of wood?

18554.text: /He’s feeding on ashes;/_his deluded mind has led him astray./He can’t save himself and say,/_“Isn’t this thing in my hand a lie?”

18555.text: §¶Remember these things, Jacob;/_Israel, for you are my servant./I formed you; you are my servant!/_I won’t forget you, Israel.

18556.text: /I swept away your rebellions like a cloud,/_and your sins like fog./Return to me,/_because I have redeemed you.

18557.text: ¶Sing, heavens, for the Lord has acted;/_shout, depths of the earth!/Burst out with a ringing cry,/you mountains, forest, and every tree in it./The Lord has redeemed Jacob,/_and will glorify himself through Israel.

18558.text: ¶The Lord your redeemer/_who formed you in the womb says:/I am the Lord, the maker of all,/_who alone stretched out the heavens,/_who spread out the earth by myself,

18559.text: /_who frustrates the omens of diviners/_and makes a mockery of magicians,/_who turns back the wise/_and turns their knowledge into folly.

18560.text: /_But who confirms the word of my servant,/_and fulfills the predictions of my messengers;/_who says about Jerusalem, “It will be resettled”;/_and who says about the cities of Judah, “They will be rebuilt,/_and I will restore their ruins”;

18561.text: /_who says to the ocean depths,/_“Dry up; I will dry your streams”;

18562.text: /_who says about Cyrus, “My shepherd—/_he will do all that I want”;/_who says about Jerusalem,/_“She will be rebuilt”;/_and who says about the temple,/_“You will be founded once again.”

18563.text: §¶The Lord says to his anointed, to Cyrus,/_whom I have grasped by the strong hand,/_to conquer nations before him,/_disarming kings,/_and opening doors before him,/_so no gates will be shut:

18564.text: /I myself will go before you,/_and I will level mountains./I will shatter bronze doors;/_I will cut through iron bars.

18565.text: /I will give you hidden treasures of secret riches,/_so you will know that I am the Lord,/_the God of Israel, who calls you by name.

18566.text: /For the sake of my servant Jacob and Israel my chosen,/_I called you by name./I gave you an honored title,/_though you didn’t know me.

18567.text: /I am the Lord, and there is no other;/_besides me there is no God./I strengthen you—/_though you don’t know me—

18568.text: /so all will know, from the rising of the sun to its setting,/_that there is nothing apart from me./I am the Lord; there’s no other.

18569.text: /_I form light and create darkness,/_make prosperity and create doom;/_I am the Lord, who does all these things.

18570.text: ¶Pour down, you heavens above,/_and let the clouds flow with righteousness./Let the earth open for salvation to bear fruit;/_let righteousness sprout as well./_I, the Lord, have created these things.

18571.text: §¶Doom to the one who argues with the potter,/_as if he were just another clay pot!/Does the clay say to the potter, “What are you making?”/_or “Your work has no handles”?

18572.text: /Doom to one who says to a father,/_“What have you fathered?”/_and to a woman,/_“With what are you in labor?”

18573.text: /The Lord, the holy one of Israel and its maker, says:/Are you questioning me about my own children?/_Are you telling me what to do with the work of my hands?

18574.text: /I myself made the earth,/_and created humans upon it./_My own hands stretched out the heavens./_I commanded all their forces.

18575.text: /I have a right to awaken Cyrus;/_I will smooth all his paths./He will build my city/_and set my exiles free,/_not for a price and not for a bribe,/_says the Lord of heavenly forces.

18576.text: ¶The Lord says:/Egypt will grow weary, Cush will be sold,/_and the tall Sabeans will cross over to you./They will be yours, and after you they will go./_In chains they will come;/_to you they will bow down./_They will plead with you:/“Truly God is with you;/_there’s no other, no other God.”

18577.text: /Surely you are a god who hides himself,/_Israel’s God and savior.

18578.text: §¶They will all be shamed and disgraced;/_the makers of idols will end up disgraced together.

18579.text: /Israel has been saved by the Lord of everlasting salvation./You won’t be shamed,/_and you won’t be disgraced forever and always.

18580.text: /For this is what the Lord said, who created the heavens,/_who is God,/_who formed the earth and made it,/_who established it,/_who didn’t create it a wasteland but formed it as a habitation:/_I, the Lord, and none other!

18581.text: /I didn’t speak in secret/_or in some land of darkness;/I didn’t say to the offspring of Jacob,/_“Seek me in chaos.”/I am the Lord, the one who speaks truth,/_who announces what is correct.

18582.text: /Gather and come,/_draw near together,/_fugitives of the nations!/Those who carry their wooden idols don’t know;/_those who pray to a god who won’t save.

18583.text: /Announce! Approach! Confer together!/_Who proclaimed this from the beginning, announced it from long ago?/Wasn’t it I, the Lord?/_There’s no other God except me,/_a righteous God and a savior;/_there’s none besides me!

18584.text: /Turn to me and be saved,/_all you ends of the earth,/_for I am God, and there’s no other.

18585.text: /I have sworn a solemn pledge;/_a word has left my mouth;/_it is reliable and won’t fail./Surely every knee will bow/and every tongue will confess;

18586.text: /_they will say, “Righteousness and strength come only from the Lord./_All who are angry with him will come to shame.

18587.text: /All the Israelites/_will be victorious and rejoice.”

18588.text: §¶Bel crouches down; Nebo cowers./_Their idols sit on animals, on beasts./The objects you once carried about/_are now borne as burdens by the weary animals.

18589.text: /They crouch down and cower together./They aren’t able to rescue the burden,/_but they themselves go into captivity.

18590.text: /Listen to me, house of Jacob,/_all that remains from the house of Israel/_who have been borne by me since pregnancy,/_whom I carried from the womb

18591.text: /_until you grow old. I am the one,/_and until you turn gray I will support you./I have done it, and I will continue to bear it;/_I will support and I will rescue.

18592.text: /To whom will you liken me and count me equal/_and compare me so that we are alike?

18593.text: /Those who pour out gold from a bag/_and weigh silver with a balance/_hire a metalworker; then he makes a god./They bow down; they worship;

18594.text: /_they carry the idol on their shoulders and support it;/_they set it down, and it stands still,/_unable to move from its place./If one cries out to it, it doesn’t answer./_It can’t save people from their distress.

18595.text: §¶Remember this and take courage;/_take it to heart, you rebels.

18596.text: /Remember the prior things—from long ago;/_I am God, and there’s no other./I am God! There’s none like me,

18597.text: /_who tells the end at the beginning,/_from ancient times things not yet done,/_saying, “My plan will stand;/_all that I decide I will do,”

18598.text: /I call a bird of prey from the east,/_a man from a distant land for my plan./As surely as I have spoken, I’ll make it happen;/_I have planned, and yes, I’ll do it.

18599.text: /Listen to me, you bullheaded people/_who are far from victory:

18600.text: /I’m bringing my victory near—it isn’t far,/_and my salvation—it won’t delay./I will establish salvation in Zion/_and grant my splendor to Israel.

18601.text: §¶Go down and sit in the dust,/_virgin Daughter Babylon!/Sit on the ground without a throne,/_Daughter Chaldea,/_because they will no longer call you tender and pampered.

18602.text: /Take the millstones and grind flour!/Remove your veil, strip off your robe,/_expose your thighs, wade through the rivers!

18603.text: /Your nakedness will be exposed,/_and your disgrace will be seen./I will take vengeance;/_no one will intervene.

18604.text: /Our redeemer has spoken;/_the Lord of heavenly forces is his name,/_the holy one of Israel.

18605.text: ¶Sit silent and go into darkness, Daughter Chaldea,/_because they will no longer call you Queen of Kingdoms.

18606.text: /I was enraged with my people;/_I made my inheritance impure/_and put them under your power./You took no pity on them./_You made your yoke heavy even on the elderly.

18607.text: /_You said, “I’m forever; I’m the eternal mistress.”/_You didn’t stop and think;/_you didn’t consider the outcome.

18608.text: /So listen to this,/luxuriant one who sits secure,/_who says in her heart,/_I’m utterly unique;/_I’ll never sit as a widow;/_I’ll never know childlessness:

18609.text: /Both of these will happen to you at once, on a single day:/_childlessness and widowhood/_will envelop you in full measure,/_despite your many sorceries,/_despite your very powerful spells.

18610.text: /You felt secure in your evil;/_you said, “No one sees me.”/Your wisdom and knowledge spun you around./_You thought to yourself, I and no one else.

18611.text: /Now evil will come against you,/_something you won’t anticipate./A curse will fall upon you,/_something you won’t be able to dispel./Destruction will come upon you suddenly,/_something you won’t foresee.

18612.text: ¶Continue with your enchantments,/_and with your many spells,/_which you have practiced since childhood./Maybe you will be able to succeed./_Maybe you will inspire terror.

18613.text: /You are weary from all your consultations;/_let the astrologers stand up and save you,/_those who gaze at the stars,/_and predict what will happen to you at each new moon.

18614.text: /They are just like stubble;/_the fire burns them./They won’t save themselves from the powerful flames./_This is no warming ember or fire to sit beside.

18615.text: /Those with whom you have wearied yourself are like this,/_those with whom you were in business from your youth:/_each has wandered off on their own way;/_none will save you.

18616.text: §¶Listen to this, house of Jacob,/_who are known by the name of Israel,/_descendants of Judah,/_who swear by the Lord’s name/_and invoke Israel’s God dishonestly and unrighteously.

18617.text: ¶They are known as residents of the holy city,/_those who depend upon the God of Israel—/_the Lord of heavenly forces is his name.

18618.text: /Past things I announced long ago;/_from my mouth I proclaimed them./_I acted suddenly, and they came about.

18619.text: /Because I know that you are stubborn,/_your neck is made of iron,/_and your forehead is bronze.

18620.text: /I informed you long ago;/_before they came about I proclaimed them to you/_so you wouldn’t say, “My idol did them;/_my wood statue and metal god commanded them.”

18621.text: /You’ve heard and seen all this—/_won’t you admit it?/From now on I’ll tell you new things,/_guarded secrets that you don’t know.

18622.text: /They are created now, not long ago;/_before today you hadn’t heard of them,/_so you won’t say, “I already knew them.”

18623.text: /You haven’t heard, nor have you known;/_as in ages past your ears are closed,/_because I knew what a traitor you were;/_you were known as a rebel from birth.

18624.text: /For the sake of my reputation I control my anger;/_for your sake I restrain my powerful radiance/_so as to not destroy you.

18625.text: /See, I have refined you, but not like silver;/_I have tested you in the furnace of misery.

18626.text: /For the sake of my reputation, for my own sake, I will act,/_for why will my name be made impure?/_I won’t give my glory to another.

18627.text: ¶Listen to me, Jacob;/_Israel, whom I called:/_I am the one;/_I am the first and I am the last.

18628.text: /My hand founded the earth;/_my strong hand spread out the heavens./_When I call to them, they all stand up.

18629.text: /Gather yourselves, all of you, and listen./_Who among you announced these things?/_“The Lord loves him./_He will do what God wants with Babylon/_and with the descendants of Chaldea.”

18630.text: /I, I have spoken and told him/_the things that will happen to him;/_I will make him succeed.

18631.text: /Come close to me; listen to this:/_Since the very beginning I haven’t spoken in secret./_Whenever anything happens, I am there./_(And now the Lord God has sent me with his spirit.)

18632.text: ¶The Lord your redeemer,/_the holy one of Israel, proclaims:/_I am the Lord your God/_who teaches you for your own good,/_who leads you in the way you should go.

18633.text: /If you would pay attention to my commands,/_your well‑being would be like a river,/_and your righteousness like the waves of the sea.

18634.text: /Your offspring would be like the sand,/_and your descendants like its grains./_Their name would never be eliminated,/_never wiped out from before me.

18635.text: ¶Go out from Babylon;/_flee from the Chaldeans!/Report this with a loud shout, proclaim it;/_broadcast it out to the end of the earth./_Say, “The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!”

18636.text: /They weren’t thirsty when he led them through the deserts./_God made water flow from the rock for them;/_split the rock, and water flowed out.

18637.text: /There is no well‑being, says the Lord, for the wicked.

18638.text: §¶Listen to me, coastlands;/_pay attention, peoples far away./The Lord called me before my birth,/_called my name when I was in my mother’s womb.

18639.text: /He made my mouth like a sharp sword,/_and hid me in the shadow of God’s own hand./He made me a sharpened arrow,/_and concealed me in God’s quiver,

18640.text: /_saying to me, “You are my servant,/_Israel, in whom I show my glory.”

18641.text: /But I said, “I have wearied myself in vain./_I have used up my strength for nothing.”/Nevertheless, the Lord will grant me justice;/_my reward is with my God.

18642.text: /And now the Lord has decided—/_the one who formed me from the womb as his servant—/_to restore Jacob to God,/_so that Israel might return to him./_Moreover, I’m honored in the Lord’s eyes;/_my God has become my strength.

18643.text: /He said: It is not enough, since you are my servant,/_to raise up the tribes of Jacob/_and to bring back the survivors of Israel./_Hence, I will also appoint you as light to the nations/_so that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.

18644.text: ¶The Lord, redeemer of Israel and its holy one,/_says to one despised,/_rejected by nations,/_to the slave of rulers:/_Kings will see and stand up;/_commanders will bow down/_on account of the Lord, who is faithful,/_the holy one of Israel,/_who has chosen you.

18645.text: /The Lord said:/At the right time, I answered you;/_on a day of salvation, I helped you./_I have guarded you,/_and given you as a covenant to the people, to restore the land,/_and to reassign deserted properties,

18646.text: /_saying to the prisoners, “Come out,”/_and to those in darkness, “Show yourselves.”/Along the roads animals will graze;/_their pasture will be on every treeless hilltop.

18647.text: /They won’t hunger or thirst;/_the burning heat and sun won’t strike them,/_because one who has compassion for them will lead them/_and will guide them by springs of water.

18648.text: /I will turn all my mountains into roads;/_my highways will be built up.

18649.text: /Look! These will come from far away./_Look! These from the north and west,/_and these from the southland.

18650.text: ¶Sing, heavens! Rejoice, earth!/_Break out, mountains, with a song./The Lord has comforted his people,/_and taken pity on those who suffer.

18651.text: §¶But Zion says, “The Lord has abandoned me;/_my Lord has forgotten me.”

18652.text: /Can a woman forget her nursing child,/_fail to pity the child of her womb?/_Even these may forget,/_but I won’t forget you.

18653.text: /Look, on my palms I’ve inscribed you;/_your walls are before me continually.

18654.text: /Your builders come quickly;/_those who destroy and demolish you will depart from you.

18655.text: /Look up all around and see:/_they are all gathered;/_they come to you./As surely as I live, says the Lord,/_you will put them all on like ornaments,/_bind them on like a bride.

18656.text: ¶As for your ruins and desolate places/_and destroyed land—/_you will soon be crowded with settlers,/_and those who swallowed you will be far away.

18657.text: /You will again hear the children who were born bereaved say,/_“The place is too crowded for me;/_make room for me to settle.”

18658.text: /And you will think to yourself,/_Who bore me these?/_I was bereaved and desolate, exiled and sent off./So who raised these?/_I was left behind, I was alone;/_where were these?

18659.text: ¶The Lord God says:/Look, I will raise my hand to the nations,/_and to the peoples I will lift up my signal./They will bring your sons in their arms,/_and will carry your daughters on their shoulders.

18660.text: /Kings will be your attendants,/_and their queens your nursemaids./With faces to the ground they will bow down to you;/_they will lick the dust from your feet./You will know that I am the Lord;/_the one who hopes in me won’t be ashamed.

18661.text: /Can loot be taken from warriors?/_Can a tyrant’s captives escape?

18662.text: /The Lord says:/Even the captives of warriors will be taken,/_and the tyrant’s loot will escape./I myself will oppose those who oppose you,/_and I myself will save your children.

18663.text: /I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh;/_and as with wine, with their own blood they will be drunk,/_so that all flesh will know that I, the Lord, am your savior,/_and the mighty one of Jacob is your redeemer.

18664.text: ¶The Lord says:/Where’s your mother’s divorce decree,/_with which I sent her away?/Or to which lender did I sell you?/_On account of your sins you were sold;/_on account of your transgressions/_your mother was sent away.

18665.text: /Why did I come and find no one?/_Why did I call when no one answered?/Is my hand too small to redeem you?/_Don’t I have enough power to save?/With my rebuke I dry up the sea/_and make the rivers into wilderness./Their fish stink from lack of water;/_they die of thirst.

18666.text: /I clothe the heavens with darkness/_and cover them with funeral clothing.

18667.text: §¶The Lord God gave me an educated tongue/_to know how to respond to the weary/_with a word that will awaken them in the morning./_God awakens my ear in the morning to listen,/_as educated people do.

18668.text: /The Lord God opened my ear;/_I didn’t rebel; I didn’t turn my back.

18669.text: /Instead, I gave my body to attackers,/_and my cheeks to beard pluckers./I didn’t hide my face/_from insults and spitting.

18670.text: /The Lord God will help me;/_therefore, I haven’t been insulted./Therefore, I set my face like flint,/_and knew I wouldn’t be ashamed.

18671.text: /The one who will declare me innocent is near./_Who will argue with me?/Let’s stand up together./_Who will bring judgment against me?/_Let him approach me.

18672.text: /Look! The Lord God will help me./_Who will condemn me?/Look, they will wear out like clothing;/_the moth will eat them.

18673.text: ¶Who among you fears the Lord?/_Who listens to the voice of his servant,/_who walks in darkness/_and has no light?/They will trust in the Lord’s name,/_and rely upon their God.

18674.text: /Look! All of you are kindling fire,/_igniting torches./_Walk by the light of your fire,/_by the torches you have ignited./_This is what will happen to you by my hand:/_you will lie down in grief.

18675.text: §¶Listen to me, you who look for righteousness, you who seek the Lord:/Look to the rock from which you were cut/_and to the quarry where you were dug.

18676.text: /Look to Abraham your ancestor,/_and to Sarah, who gave you birth./They were alone when I called them, but I blessed them/_and made them many.

18677.text: /The Lord will comfort Zion;/_he will comfort all her ruins./He will make her desert like Eden/_and her wilderness like the Lord’s garden./Happiness and joy will be found in her—/_thanks and the sound of singing.

18678.text: §¶Pay attention to me, my people;/_listen to me, my nation,/_for teaching will go out from me,/_my justice, as a light to the nations.

18679.text: /_I will quickly bring my victory./My salvation is on its way,/_and my arm will judge the peoples./_The coastlands hope for me;/_they wait for my judgment.

18680.text: /Look up to the heavens,/_and gaze at the earth beneath./_The heavens will disappear like smoke,/_the earth will wear out like clothing,/_and its inhabitants will die like gnats./But my salvation will endure forever,/_and my righteousness will be unbroken.

18681.text: /Listen to me, you who know what is right,/_people who carry my teaching in your heart:/_Don’t fear human scorn,/_and don’t be upset when they abuse you.

18682.text: /The moth will eat them as if they were clothing,/_and the worm will eat them like wool,/_but my righteousness is forever,/_and my salvation for all generations.

18683.text: §¶Awake, awake, put on strength,/_arm of the Lord./Awake as in times past,/_generations long ago./Aren’t you the one who crushed Rahab,/_who pierced the dragon?

18684.text: /Didn’t you dry up the sea,/_the waters of the great deep?/_And didn’t you make the redeemed a road to cross/_through the depths of the sea,/_a road for the redeemed to pass?

18685.text: /Then let those ransomed by the Lord return/_and come to Zion with singing/_and with everlasting joy upon their heads./Let happiness and joy overwhelm them;/_let grief and groaning flee.

18686.text: ¶I, I am the one who comforts you./Why should you fear humans who will die,/_mortals who are treated like grass?

18687.text: /You forgot the Lord your maker,/_the one who stretched out the heavens/_and founded the earth./_You were continually afraid, all day long,/_on account of the oppressor’s wrath—/_a fear by which they intend to destroy you./_Where now is the oppressor’s wrath?

18688.text: /The imprisoned ones will soon be released;/_they won’t die in the pit/_or even lack bread.

18689.text: /I am the Lord your God,/_who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—/_the Lord of heavenly forces is his name.

18690.text: /I put my words in your mouth/_and hid you in the shadow of my hand,/_stretching out the heavens, founding the earth,/_and saying to Zion, “You are my people.”

18691.text: §¶Wake yourself, wake yourself!/_Rise up, Jerusalem,/_who drank the cup of wrath from the Lord’s hand./_You drank; you drained the goblet of reeling.

18692.text: /_There’s no one to guide her among all the children she bore;/_there’s no one to take her by the hand among all the children she raised.

18693.text: /These two things have happened to you—/_Who will be sorry for you?—/_destruction and devastation,/_famine and sword—/_who will comfort you?

18694.text: /Your children passed out;/_they lay at the head of every street like antelope in a net,/_filled with the Lord’s wrath,/_with the rebuke of your God.

18695.text: ¶Therefore, hear this, suffering one,/_who is drunk, but not from wine.

18696.text: /The Lord, your Lord and your God,/_who contends for his people, says:/_Look, I have taken the cup of reeling,/_the goblet of my wrath, from your hand./_You will no longer drink from it.

18697.text: /I will put it in the hand of your tormentors,/_who said to you,/_“Lie down so that we can walk on you./_Make your back like the ground,/_like a street for those walking on it.”

18698.text: §¶Awake, awake,/_put on your strength, Zion!/_Put on your splendid clothing,/_Jerusalem, you holy city;/_for the uncircumcised and unclean/_will no longer come into you.

18699.text: /Shake the dust off yourself;/_rise up; sit enthroned, Jerusalem./Loose the bonds from your neck,/_captive Daughter Zion!

18700.text: ¶The Lord proclaims:/You were sold for nothing,/_and you will be redeemed without money.

18701.text: /The Lord God proclaims:/Long ago my people went down/_to reside in Egypt./_Moreover, Assyria has oppressed them without cause.

18702.text: /And now what have I here? says the Lord./_My people are taken away for nothing./Their rulers wail, says the Lord,/_and continually all day long my name is despised.

18703.text: /Therefore, my people will know my name on that day;/_I’m the one who promises it; I’m here.

18704.text: §¶How beautiful upon the mountains/_are the feet of a messenger/_who proclaims peace,/_who brings good news,/_who proclaims salvation,/_who says to Zion, “Your God rules!”

18705.text: /Listen! Your lookouts lift their voice;/_they sing out together!/_Right before their eyes they see the Lord returning to Zion.

18706.text: ¶Break into song together, you ruins of Jerusalem!/The Lord has comforted his people and has redeemed Jerusalem.

18707.text: /The Lord has bared his holy arm in view of all the nations;/_all the ends of the earth have seen our God’s victory.

18708.text: ¶Depart! Depart! Go out from there!/_Unclean! Don’t touch!/_Get out of that place; purify yourselves,/_carriers of the Lord’s equipment!

18709.text: /You won’t go out in a rush,/_nor will you run away,/_because the one going before you is the Lord;/_your rear guard is the God of Israel.

18710.text: §¶Look, my servant will succeed./_He will be exalted and lifted very high.

18711.text: /Just as many were appalled by you,/_he too appeared disfigured, inhuman,/_his appearance unlike that of mortals.

18712.text: /But he will astonish many nations./_Kings will be silenced because of him,/_because they will see what they haven’t seen before;/_what they haven’t heard before, they will ponder.

18713.text: ¶Who can believe what we have heard,/_and for whose sake has the Lord’s arm been revealed?

18714.text: /He grew up like a young plant before us,/_like a root from dry ground./He possessed no splendid form for us to see,/_no desirable appearance.

18715.text: /He was despised and avoided by others;/_a man who suffered, who knew sickness well./Like someone from whom people hid their faces,/_he was despised, and we didn’t think about him.

18716.text: ¶It was certainly our sickness that he carried,/_and our sufferings that he bore,/_but we thought him afflicted,/_struck down by God and tormented.

18717.text: /He was pierced because of our rebellions/_and crushed because of our crimes./_He bore the punishment that made us whole;/_by his wounds we are healed.

18718.text: /Like sheep we had all wandered away,/_each going its own way,/_but the Lord let fall on him all our crimes.

18719.text: ¶He was oppressed and tormented,/_but didn’t open his mouth./Like a lamb being brought to slaughter,/_like a ewe silent before her shearers,/_he didn’t open his mouth.

18720.text: ¶Due to an unjust ruling he was taken away,/_and his fate—who will think about it?/He was eliminated from the land of the living,/_struck dead because of my people’s rebellion.

18721.text: /His grave was among the wicked,/_his tomb with evildoers,/_though he had done no violence,/_and had spoken nothing false.

18722.text: ¶But the Lord wanted to crush him/_and to make him suffer./If his life is offered as restitution,/_he will see his offspring; he will enjoy long life./_The Lord’s plans will come to fruition through him.

18723.text: /After his deep anguish he will see light, and he will be satisfied./Through his knowledge, the righteous one, my servant,/_will make many righteous,/_and will bear their guilt.

18724.text: /Therefore, I will give him a share with the great,/_and he will divide the spoil with the strong,/_in return for exposing his life to death/_and being numbered with rebels,/_though he carried the sin of many/_and pleaded on behalf of those who rebelled.

18725.text: §¶Sing, barren woman who has borne no child;/_break forth into singing and cry out,/_you who were never in labor,/_for the children of the wife who has been deserted will be more numerous than the children of the married, says the Lord.

18726.text: /Enlarge the site of your tent,/_and stretch out the drapes of your dwellings;/_don’t hold back./_Lengthen your tent ropes and strengthen your stakes.

18727.text: /_To the right and to the left you will burst out,/_and your children will possess the nations’ land/_and settle their desolate cities.

18728.text: ¶Don’t fear,/_because you won’t be ashamed;/_don’t be dismayed,/_because you won’t be disgraced./You will forget the shame of your youth;/_you’ll no longer remember the disgrace of your widowhood.

18729.text: /The one marrying you is the one who made you—/_the Lord of heavenly forces is his name./The one redeeming you is the holy one of Israel,/_the one called the God of all the earth.

18730.text: /As an abandoned and dejected woman the Lord has summoned you;/_as a young wife when she is rejected,/_says your God.

18731.text: /For a brief moment I abandoned you,/_but with great mercy I will bring you back.

18732.text: /_In an outburst of rage,/_I hid my face from you for a moment,/_but with everlasting love I have consoled you,/_says your redeemer, the Lord.

18733.text: ¶These are like the days of Noah for me,/_when I promised that Noah’s waters would never again cover the earth./_Likewise I promise not to rage against you or rebuke you.

18734.text: /The mountains may shift,/_and the hills may be shaken,/_but my faithful love won’t shift from you,/_and my covenant of peace won’t be shaken,/_says the Lord, the one who pities you.

18735.text: ¶Suffering one, storm‑tossed, uncomforted,/_look, I am setting your gemstones/_in silvery metal/_and your foundations with sapphires.

18736.text: /I will make your towers of rubies,/_and your gates of beryl,/_and all your walls of precious jewels.

18737.text: /_All your children will be disciples of the Lord—/_I will make peace abound for your children.

18738.text: /You will be firmly founded in righteousness./_You will stay far from oppression because you won’t fear,/_far from terror because it won’t come near you.

18739.text: /If anyone attacks you, it’s none of my doing./_Whoever attacks you will fall because of you.

18740.text: /Look, I myself created the metalworker who blows the fire of coal and who produces a tool for his work./_And I myself created the looter to destroy.

18741.text: /No weapon fashioned against you will succeed,/_and you may condemn every tongue that disputes with you./This is the heritage of the Lord’s servants,/_whose righteousness comes from me, says the Lord.

18742.text: §¶All of you who are thirsty, come to the water!/Whoever has no money, come, buy food and eat!/Without money, at no cost, buy wine and milk!

18743.text: /Why spend money for what isn’t food,/_and your earnings for what doesn’t satisfy?/Listen carefully to me and eat what is good;/_enjoy the richest of feasts.

18744.text: /Listen and come to me;/_listen, and you will live./I will make an everlasting covenant with you,/_my faithful loyalty to David.

18745.text: /Look, I made him a witness to the peoples,/_a prince and commander of peoples.
